description: Metasploit is a popular penetration testing software, which is represented as a suite of tools, which can go through the whole penetration testing process. Whether using Windows or Linux, Metasploit can be a powerful tool to test network security and is positioned as something that network administrators, penetration testers and even developers could use, which can make it a valuable addition to oneâ€™s security toolkit.
name: Metasploit
subtitle: Configuration of Metasploit

episodes.title: Metasploit Overview
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1

[MUSIC]

2

Got another exciting set of videos

What can I do with Metasploit?

>> Metasploit, I guess the question is,
as far as pen testing's concerned,

what can't you do?

11

It's open source so people can add stuff

12

And it can do just

In fact,

the suite of tools itself,
you can pretty much go through

15
00:00:51.820 --> 00:00:55.960
the whole penetration testing
process just with Metasploit.

16
00:00:55.960 --> 00:00:58.830
So there's just that much there.

17
00:00:58.830 --> 00:01:01.580
So it's really something
that you gotta get in and

So it's incredibly powerful and very

21

of your pen testing process, you're still
gonna get a lot of mileage out of it.

22
00:01:17.990 --> 00:01:22.120
This will add a whole extra level

23
00:01:22.120 --> 00:01:23.530
>> And you said it was open source so

00:01:23.530 --> 00:01:27.860
it's freely accessible,
runs on different platforms I'm assuming?

25
00:01:27.860 --> 00:01:30.800
>> Yes, it runs on Linux and

26
00:01:30.800 --> 00:01:34.310
Windows, and I believe, yeah,
Unix, you can get it for that too.

27
00:01:34.310 --> 00:01:36.023
It's close enough, I guess, right?

28
00:01:36.023 --> 00:01:37.313
>> [LAUGH]
>> So you can get it on there.

29
00:01:37.313 --> 00:01:42.383
So we're gonna be focusing on using
it on Linux, but like I said,

30
00:01:42.383 --> 00:01:47.020
you can get it on Windows and
do your stuff over there.

31
00:01:47.020 --> 00:01:50.180
Ironically enough is if you go ahead and

32
00:01:50.180 --> 00:01:52.340
you're pretty much gonna get

33
00:01:52.340 --> 00:01:53.310
You get the command line.

34
00:01:53.310 --> 00:01:53.970
Line.
So yeah, you

35
00:01:53.970 --> 00:01:56.720
could move the command line here or
you can move it here.

36
00:01:56.720 --> 00:02:00.456
But you're getting a command line and
you'll like it.

37
00:02:00.456 --> 00:02:03.690
>> [LAUGH] There's no fancy GUI for us to
click through or anything like that, huh?

38
00:02:03.690 --> 00:02:06.545
>> Very, very little on that.

39
00:02:06.545 --> 00:02:10.585
And you'll get pretty much everything
right throughout the command line, so

40
00:02:10.585 --> 00:02:14.535
there are some GUI based things in there
that are either part of the product or

41
00:02:14.535 --> 00:02:16.585
has been added on by a third party.

42
00:02:16.585 --> 00:02:21.285
What you're gonna be looking at command
line for the most part and we're

43
00:02:21.285 --> 00:02:25.375
just gonna go ahead and keep things simple
and use it right inside of Kali Linux.

44
00:02:25.375 --> 00:02:29.620
You know we did a whole set
of shows on Kali Linux so

45
00:02:29.620 --> 00:02:32.900
if you're going through the whole process
here, you can watch the Kali Linux one and

46
00:02:32.900 --> 00:02:37.610
get familiar with that and then jump right
over into this and kind of see how this

47
00:02:37.610 --> 00:02:40.630
fits in with that product and
the stuff we covered over there.

48
00:02:40.630 --> 00:02:43.870
>> And this is something I could use
if I was a penetration tester and

49
00:02:43.870 --> 00:02:45.680
I was doing it for
money or for a business.

50
00:02:45.680 --> 00:02:47.170
This is a product I could use.

51
00:02:47.170 --> 00:02:51.360
Also if I was just a network admin or
part of the security team in a company.

52
00:02:51.360 --> 00:02:53.330
Something I could use
to test my own stuff or

53
00:02:53.330 --> 00:02:55.200
make sure everything was on the up and up?

54
00:02:55.200 --> 00:02:59.420
>> Yes, it's very well positioned as
something that a security administrator or

55
00:02:59.420 --> 00:03:01.204
somebody along those lines would use.

56
00:03:01.204 --> 00:03:05.370
It could be used by developers, it could
be used by a number of different people.

57
00:03:05.370 --> 00:03:06.440
Network admins, yeah,

58
00:03:06.440 --> 00:03:09.439
I could see some tools in there that they
might get some mileage out of as well.

59
00:03:10.450 --> 00:03:14.120
I'm not sure how far they'd be able
to take it there, but who knows?

60
00:03:14.120 --> 00:03:16.620
Network admins can always find, you give

61
00:03:16.620 --> 00:03:17.310
I can use it.

62
00:03:17.310 --> 00:03:18.290
So who knows?

63
00:03:18.290 --> 00:03:20.740
They'll probably find some
way to use it over there.

64
00:03:20.740 --> 00:03:21.270
>> Good deal.

65
00:03:21.270 --> 00:03:24.890
All right, well we've got a bunch of

66
00:03:24.890 --> 00:03:30.186
Dealing with Metasploit, so everybody
stay tuned, sit back, relax, and enjoy.

67
00:03:30.186 --> 00:03:36.199
[MUSIC]

episodes.title: What is Metasploit
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

[MUSIC]

Hello, and
welcome to another episode of ITProTV.

3
00:00:13.050 --> 00:00:15.130
I'm your host Mike Roderick.

4

And with me today is Mr. Sean Oriyano.

5
00:00:16.637 --> 00:00:17.601
How are you doing Sean?

6
00:00:17.601 --> 00:00:18.194
>> I'm doing pretty good.

7
00:00:18.194 --> 00:00:19.000
How are you doing?

8
00:00:19.000 --> 00:00:20.210
>> I'm doing fantastic.

9
00:00:20.210 --> 00:00:21.250
Excited to be here.

10
00:00:21.250 --> 00:00:24.740
We were just getting started
in our Metasploit videos.

11
00:00:24.740 --> 00:00:27.950
We're gonna be taking a look at
a program called Metasploit.

12
00:00:27.950 --> 00:00:32.210
Something we can use to do penetration
tests amongst other things.

13
00:00:32.210 --> 00:00:36.070
So Sean, before we dive into all the cool
stuff that we can do with it, let's talk

14
00:00:36.070 --> 00:00:41.510
a little bit about what it is and why
we would wanna use good old Metasploit.

15
00:00:41.510 --> 00:00:43.270
>> Yeah,
that's the million dollar question-

16
00:00:43.270 --> 00:00:43.862
>> [LAUGH]

17
00:00:43.862 --> 00:00:46.235
>> I think when people really look at

18
00:00:46.235 --> 00:00:49.010
Metasploit is why do I even care?

19
00:00:49.010 --> 00:00:50.690
Why this tool?

20
00:00:50.690 --> 00:00:52.389
Because you see it mentioned in so

21
00:00:52.389 --> 00:00:56.586
many different contexts especially
throughout the penetration testing world.

22
00:00:56.586 --> 00:01:00.834
You hear Metasploit this and
Metasploit that, but it seems to be it's

23
00:01:00.834 --> 00:01:05.370
mentioned a lot, some people have
a little bit of knowledge here or there,

24
00:01:05.370 --> 00:01:09.960
and then there's very few people who
have really gone in and used it.

25
00:01:09.960 --> 00:01:14.200
So it's one of those things you kind
of really got to discuss what it is.

26
00:01:14.200 --> 00:01:18.174
So Metasploit yes,
it is indeed a penetration testing tool.

27
00:01:18.174 --> 00:01:21.273
That's one of the functions that it plays.

28
00:01:21.273 --> 00:01:23.434
It's got a tremendous sweep and

29
00:01:23.434 --> 00:01:28.877
pretty broad capability across the board
as far as penetration testing tools and

30
00:01:28.877 --> 00:01:34.780
it even integrates with a lot of the tools

31
00:01:34.780 --> 00:01:38.311
So that's actually kinda good

32
00:01:38.311 --> 00:01:41.135

33

34

35
00:01:50.129 --> 00:01:55.216
One that comes to mind for

36
00:01:55.216 --> 00:01:59.810
Nmap does integrate directly

37
00:01:59.810 --> 00:02:02.110

38
00:02:02.110 --> 00:02:07.360
If you didnt think Nmap was in a nerdy

39
00:02:07.360 --> 00:02:11.470
it's got another level of stuff it can
do when you put it in with Metasploit.

40
00:02:11.470 --> 00:02:13.370
So that's kind of a neat thing there.

41
00:02:13.370 --> 00:02:17.796
So it does have a lot of capabilities
in the penetration testing area,

42
00:02:17.796 --> 00:02:22.671
and it can go from the beginning of the
penetration testing process all the way

43
00:02:22.671 --> 00:02:24.258
on through pretty much.

44
00:02:24.258 --> 00:02:28.042
I would say pretty much the only thing
it can't do it is really develop

45
00:02:28.042 --> 00:02:30.100
your reports for you.

46
00:02:30.100 --> 00:02:33.170
We saw in Kali itself
when we did that show,

47
00:02:33.170 --> 00:02:36.510
we saw that Kali itself had tools for
doing reporting.

48
00:02:36.510 --> 00:02:40.665
And we saw when we did our CDH show
that we had tools that we could get from

49
00:02:40.665 --> 00:02:42.721
different areas to do reporting.

50
00:02:42.721 --> 00:02:47.251
Metasploit doesn't have that, but
with the data that Metasploit gets, if

51
00:02:47.251 --> 00:02:52.230
you're using it in Kali like we have well,
you've got the reporting tools there.

52
00:02:52.230 --> 00:02:54.490
So it doesn't really need to do that, so

53
00:02:54.490 --> 00:02:58.050
you've got everything you've need
as far as penetration testing goes.

54
00:02:58.050 --> 00:03:02.500
But like I said, that's just one item
off the list that you could use it for.

55
00:03:02.500 --> 00:03:05.333
What we're looking at it for,
but just when you can use it for.

56
00:03:05.333 --> 00:03:06.876
>> What other kind of
things might we use it for?

57
00:03:06.876 --> 00:03:08.095
>> You can also use it.

58
00:03:08.095 --> 00:03:15.880
It's got a somewhat notorious reputation
on the forensic side of the house.

59
00:03:15.880 --> 00:03:20.830
Because if we go back to what we
did when we discussed forensics.

60
00:03:20.830 --> 00:03:22.272
I want to thank [INAUDIBLE] forensics for
us.

61
00:03:22.272 --> 00:03:25.479
We wanna make sure that we
preserve the time and date and

62
00:03:25.479 --> 00:03:27.022
stuff like that on files.

63
00:03:27.022 --> 00:03:29.934
So we know when they were accessed,
when they were modified,

64
00:03:29.934 --> 00:03:32.140
when they were created,
all that good stuff.

65
00:03:32.140 --> 00:03:35.410
Well, Metasploit actually
has tools in there and

66
00:03:35.410 --> 00:03:38.370
this is just one of the tools
that it has that can do this.

67
00:03:38.370 --> 00:03:42.100
It can actually go through and
destroy some of that forensic evidence.

68
00:03:42.100 --> 00:03:45.978
So if someone were to have access to this
and know how to use this the right way,

69
00:03:45.978 --> 00:03:48.900
they could very easily run across
a whole batch of files and

70
00:03:48.900 --> 00:03:52.562
overwrite all the time and date stamps
on it and just ruin your whole day.

71
00:03:52.562 --> 00:03:56.361
[LAUGH] If you're going to be trying
to collect that evidence to take to

72
00:03:56.361 --> 00:04:00.226
court because that's an important
part to know when it was created and

73
00:04:00.226 --> 00:04:02.060
what those attributes are.

74
00:04:02.060 --> 00:04:03.280
They can just go ahead and overwrite it.

75
00:04:03.280 --> 00:04:05.190
It has that ability.

76
00:04:05.190 --> 00:04:08.770
It might be a little bit of
something that you don't wanna do,

77
00:04:08.770 --> 00:04:10.430
but you should talk about it.

78
00:04:10.430 --> 00:04:11.903
At least you should know it's there.

79
00:04:11.903 --> 00:04:14.910
A lot of people don't
know that that's there.

80
00:04:14.910 --> 00:04:19.200
And who knows, you inadvertently give
someone the ability to access to this cuz

81
00:04:19.200 --> 00:04:21.330
it can be remote accessed.

82
00:04:21.330 --> 00:04:24.270
Someone who uses this,
they can very easily go through and

83
00:04:24.270 --> 00:04:28.700
start destroying stuff before you
even realized what's happened.

84
00:04:28.700 --> 00:04:32.725
>> Is there a legitimate purpose for that
functionality other than anti forensics

85
00:04:32.725 --> 00:04:34.779
type thing or is that really what it's?

86
00:04:34.779 --> 00:04:36.218
>> I'll say yeah,
just to be nice about it.

87
00:04:36.218 --> 00:04:41.120
>> [LAUGH]
>> Someone probably had a reason to do it.

88
00:04:41.120 --> 00:04:45.003
I can't think of why, but someone probably
had a reason for it, so I'll be nice and

89
00:04:45.003 --> 00:04:46.625
optimistic and say yeah, you do.

90
00:04:46.625 --> 00:04:47.810
>> Right.

91
00:04:47.810 --> 00:04:52.392
>> But is is definitely there and it is
something that's documented that if you

92
00:04:52.392 --> 00:04:55.971
want to see that or use that for
whatever reason it is there,

93
00:04:55.971 --> 00:05:00.785
it's very well documented out there on
the Internet and in forensics circles.

94
00:05:00.785 --> 00:05:04.545
>> So this is just one of those tools that
rides the fences like a lot of them do.

95
00:05:04.545 --> 00:05:06.724
It can be used for good,
it can be used for

96
00:05:06.724 --> 00:05:07.536
evil-
>> [LAUGH]

97
00:05:07.536 --> 00:05:08.493
>> Depending on what side of the fence

98
00:05:08.493 --> 00:05:09.057
you're on I guess.

99
00:05:09.057 --> 00:05:14.292
>> Yeah, it depends on what the intent
of the user of it actually is.

100
00:05:14.292 --> 00:05:19.090
Once you learn all the stuff
that Metasploit can do for you.

101
00:05:19.090 --> 00:05:22.030
And like I said,
has a pretty deep bench as far as tools.

102
00:05:22.030 --> 00:05:24.969
And that's not including the stuff
that you can get third party and

103
00:05:24.969 --> 00:05:27.238
start popping in there,
all these extra modules.

104
00:05:27.238 --> 00:05:30.660
You can just have so
much at your disposal.

105
00:05:30.660 --> 00:05:31.909
It's just a question of what
you are gonna do with it?

106
00:05:31.909 --> 00:05:37.954
And you're gonna see that as we go
through all these segments on Metasploit,

107
00:05:37.954 --> 00:05:42.697
you'll see that there's just so
many different things that

108
00:05:42.697 --> 00:05:46.789
you can do to access hosts
remotely to sweep hosts and

109
00:05:46.789 --> 00:05:50.970
find out what they are running and
what they are.

110
00:05:50.970 --> 00:05:55.530
And so you'd get them to call you and
open up shells, call you up and

111
00:05:55.530 --> 00:05:59.950
give you a shell so you can do stuff
here and access something out there.

112
00:05:59.950 --> 00:06:06.810
It's got a lot of just nice and pretty
powerful capabilities but how you use it?

113
00:06:06.810 --> 00:06:07.701
It's really up to you.

114
00:06:07.701 --> 00:06:11.066
We're hoping that you use it for
good and not for evil, but who knows?

115
00:06:11.066 --> 00:06:13.006
>> [LAUGH] Keep on the good side.

116
00:06:13.006 --> 00:06:15.921
>> [LAUGH]
>> But the dark side has cookies.

117
00:06:15.921 --> 00:06:17.324
>> [LAUGH]
>> Yeah, there you go.

118
00:06:17.324 --> 00:06:21.279
>> [LAUGH]
>> So Metasploit then a tool that I can

119
00:06:21.279 --> 00:06:25.648
use for penetration testing was one of
the biggest purposes of it I guess.

120
00:06:25.648 --> 00:06:26.425
>> Yeah.

121
00:06:26.425 --> 00:06:30.862
>> And then anti forensics is another
purpose that we can use it for that.

122
00:06:30.862 --> 00:06:32.702
And you got in here like
software development,

123
00:06:32.702 --> 00:06:35.320
I could see where this could
play into that as well?

124
00:06:35.320 --> 00:06:39.290
>> Yes most definitely, it is used quite
a bit by people over on that side of

125
00:06:39.290 --> 00:06:44.270
the house and there's very good reason for
that not only does it have all

126
00:06:44.270 --> 00:06:48.400
these tools that can check for
just say, security holes in general.

127
00:06:48.400 --> 00:06:52.130
But it's one of the tools
that can help you locate and

128
00:06:52.130 --> 00:06:57.920

overflows and little defects in code.

129
00:06:57.920 --> 00:07:00.499
It can find ways to kind of
get through those cracks.

130
00:07:00.499 --> 00:07:05.955
So you can use this tool to develop
these exploits to get in there and

131
00:07:05.955 --> 00:07:09.180

132
00:07:09.180 --> 00:07:13.220
Not saying it's easy to do that,

133
00:07:13.220 --> 00:07:15.970

134
00:07:15.970 --> 00:07:18.700
this makes it a lot easier
than it would be otherwise.

135
00:07:18.700 --> 00:07:23.610
And that's why you'll see people like

136
00:07:23.610 --> 00:07:26.490
It's not uncommon to see
it sitting on their desk or

137
00:07:26.490 --> 00:07:30.360
in their tool set someplace where
they will check things out, and

138
00:07:30.360 --> 00:07:32.570

applications out with it.

139
00:07:32.570 --> 00:07:36.270
They will check locally hosted apps,
distributed apps.

140
00:07:36.270 --> 00:07:39.920
And I've seen a lot with web apps and
SQL stuff.

141
00:07:39.920 --> 00:07:45.630
You actually have stuff built into
Metasploit that can check SQL and

142
00:07:45.630 --> 00:07:47.030
Oracle databases.

143
00:07:47.030 --> 00:07:48.920
It's right there from the GetGo.

144
00:07:48.920 --> 00:07:50.778
So it's very, very useful for

145
00:07:50.778 --> 00:07:54.785
those people to employ in whatever
their testing development is.

146
00:07:54.785 --> 00:07:59.480
>> Yeah, we've talked about that in our
other episodes, where we did Kali, Linux.

147
00:07:59.480 --> 00:08:01.965
We've talked about that in I think,
CEH as well.

148
00:08:01.965 --> 00:08:03.659
And some of our security shows.

149
00:08:03.659 --> 00:08:06.481
As an app tester or an application
developer or website tester,

150
00:08:06.481 --> 00:08:08.587
we've talked about all
the vulnerabilities.

151
00:08:08.587 --> 00:08:13.038
And we've said, well, the problem is,
like with buffer overflows or with input

152
00:08:13.038 --> 00:08:17.180
validation, is it was on the development
size where that hole was created.

153
00:08:17.180 --> 00:08:19.680
So if they've got a tool they can use,
to look for

154
00:08:19.680 --> 00:08:23.060
those holes before they put out that

00:21:39.340 --> 00:21:42.920
it doesn't have to be just on Kali
by the way, you can put it on

373
00:21:42.920 --> 00:21:47.690
just about every major version of
Linux you can have it installed on.

374
00:21:47.690 --> 00:21:50.080
But Kali seems to be the most
likely one you can put it on,

375
00:21:50.080 --> 00:21:51.880
because of all the other
tools that are there and

376
00:21:51.880 --> 00:21:56.220
since it does exist there anyway,
it seems like a good fit for that.

377
00:21:56.220 --> 00:22:01.030
So it just seems that if you're
going to be using this Linux and

378
00:22:01.030 --> 00:22:05.480
Klinux seems to be the combination that
you'd have, because you have access to

379
00:22:05.480 --> 00:22:08.570
Metasploit, you have access to
the other tools, they all integrate.

380
00:22:08.570 --> 00:22:13.265
Why not just just have all the tools
ready, instead of just having it as

381
00:22:13.265 --> 00:22:19.425
an island unto itself or maybe not
having the same integration on Windows.

382
00:22:19.425 --> 00:22:26.550
So, I would throw that out there, and
just one little other little point on this

383
00:22:26.550 --> 00:22:31.770
is when you look at Metasploit,
there's a lot of cases out there.

384
00:22:31.770 --> 00:22:34.800
I don't know if it's kind of like
the nose in the air type thing.

385
00:22:34.800 --> 00:22:39.070
But a lot of cases when people
have developed modules or

386
00:22:39.070 --> 00:22:41.500
doing something revolving
around Metasploit,

387
00:22:41.500 --> 00:22:43.640
they will almost always go
right over to the Linux side.

388
00:22:43.640 --> 00:22:46.600
And some of them will say, yeah,
if you have problems with Windows,

389
00:22:46.600 --> 00:22:51.095
or writing this on the Mac OS or
what have you, don't call me.

390
00:22:51.095 --> 00:22:52.750
>> [LAUGH]
>> That's kind of their attitude.

391
00:22:52.750 --> 00:22:56.990
I mean, yeah,
that's a little bit of a bad and

392
00:22:56.990 --> 00:22:59.640
negative attitude on it,
but be prepared for that.

393
00:22:59.640 --> 00:23:02.550
They just kind of consider
that this is a Linux tool,

394
00:23:02.550 --> 00:23:03.969
even though it could run over there.

395
00:23:05.280 --> 00:23:09.750
We prefer you run it on
Linux instead of Windows.

396
00:23:09.750 --> 00:23:14.840
Rapid 7 doesn't say that and
I don't see them endorsing saying,

397
00:23:14.840 --> 00:23:16.520
oh yeah you've got to run it on Linux.

398
00:23:16.520 --> 00:23:17.390
You can't run it on Windows.

399
00:23:17.390 --> 00:23:18.980
But we'll make it available.

400
00:23:18.980 --> 00:23:22.580
I don't see them actually
pushing that view, but

401
00:23:22.580 --> 00:23:27.780
the community outside of that seems to
kind of skew that way, so another reason.

402
00:23:27.780 --> 00:23:29.440
>> Yeah, that's a lot of work for
those developers.

403
00:23:29.440 --> 00:23:31.670
They're giving away free plugins for

404
00:23:31.670 --> 00:23:33.440
this tool they've always
developed to run on Linux.

405
00:23:33.440 --> 00:23:36.030
I think some of them sometimes
are just like, I'm not going to spend

406
00:23:36.030 --> 00:23:39.000
the time on something to get
it to port over to Windows,

407
00:23:39.000 --> 00:23:41.850
you can use it on Linux or
you can not use it all type thing.

408
00:23:41.850 --> 00:23:42.630
>> Yeah, exactly.

409
00:23:42.630 --> 00:23:48.180
There's, they may have been for
years been on Linux,

410
00:23:48.180 --> 00:23:51.360
because it's so open and they can do all
the free development and everything for

411
00:23:51.360 --> 00:23:55.400
it, that they just don't want to
bother with doing anything on Windows,

412
00:23:55.400 --> 00:23:59.520
because there's just so many complexities,
and intricacies over there,

413
00:23:59.520 --> 00:24:02.490
that are just like, forget it,
I'm not doing that.

414
00:24:02.490 --> 00:24:06.090
So, don't be surprised if
you run into that attitude.

415
00:24:06.090 --> 00:24:12.170
Now, does that mean those plugins and
stuff like that won't run on Windows?

416
00:24:12.170 --> 00:24:15.450
No, it doesn't mean that, it just means
they're probably not going to help you

417
00:24:15.450 --> 00:24:18.290
get those plugins to run on
Windows if you have a problem.

418
00:24:18.290 --> 00:24:21.130
I just saw something like that last night,
as a matter of fact,

419
00:24:21.130 --> 00:24:22.250
where someone had their FAQ.

420
00:24:22.250 --> 00:24:25.190
He's like, hey, had a problem on Windows?

421
00:24:25.190 --> 00:24:26.512
Well, that's unfortunate.

422
00:24:26.512 --> 00:24:29.235
>> [LAUGH] [CROSSTALK]
>> That was kind of their attitude.

423
00:24:29.235 --> 00:24:29.810
>> Run Linux.

424
00:24:29.810 --> 00:24:30.995
[LAUGH]
>> Yeah, that was

425
00:24:30.995 --> 00:24:32.855
basically the attitude in there.

426
00:24:32.855 --> 00:24:35.005
It was very nicely phrased,
I'll tell you that.

427
00:24:35.005 --> 00:24:40.630
But it was basically saying yeah, go run
on Linux or I'm not bothering with you.

428
00:24:40.630 --> 00:24:41.659
That was kind of it.

429
00:24:41.659 --> 00:24:46.610
But, even though we're running on Linux,

430
00:24:46.610 --> 00:24:49.700
here, don't take it as, hey that's
the only place you could run it as, and

431
00:24:49.700 --> 00:24:51.970
we're not going to be all snobby about it.

432
00:24:51.970 --> 00:24:54.251
But, just be aware of those factors.

433
00:24:54.251 --> 00:24:55.040
>> We're not going to help you.
[LAUGH]

434
00:24:55.040 --> 00:24:57.370
>> Yeah, we're not going to help you.

435
00:24:57.370 --> 00:24:59.065
>> We're just kidding folks.

436
00:24:59.065 --> 00:25:00.010
>> [LAUGH]
>> All right, well Sean,

437
00:25:00.010 --> 00:25:01.010
a lot of great information.

438
00:25:01.010 --> 00:25:04.460
You really got me excited about watching
these Metasploit episodes that we've got

439
00:25:04.460 --> 00:25:05.650
coming your way.

440
00:25:05.650 --> 00:25:08.570
Anything else you want to throw
in our little kind of a what

441
00:25:08.570 --> 00:25:09.930
is Metasploit episode here?

442
00:25:11.310 --> 00:25:13.510
>> Not really much, except you
need to start downloading this so

443
00:25:13.510 --> 00:25:16.560
we can get started on doing the rest
of the stuff of Metasploit.

444
00:25:16.560 --> 00:25:20.660
We got a lot of things we're going to
do revolving around these areas, so

445
00:25:20.660 --> 00:25:24.330
yeah I think we'll be really excited
when they see what it can do,

446
00:25:24.330 --> 00:25:26.430
especially as a penetration tool.

447
00:25:26.430 --> 00:25:29.270
What it adds to the whole mix.

448
00:25:29.270 --> 00:25:29.960
>> Fantastic,

449
00:25:29.960 --> 00:25:31.034
all right well I know I'm excited
>> Excited.

450
00:25:31.034 --> 00:25:34.217
I hope you guys are too, but for
now signing off for IT Pro TV,

451
00:25:34.217 --> 00:25:35.352
I'm Mike Roderick.

452
00:25:35.352 --> 00:25:37.430
>> And I'm Sean Oriyano.

453
00:25:37.430 --> 00:25:42.829
[MUSIC]

episodes.title: Versions of Metasploit
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:11.195 --> 00:00:14.030
Hello, and
welcome to another episode of ITProTV.

3
00:00:14.030 --> 00:00:16.740
I'm your host, Mike Rodrick, and
with me today is Mr. Sean Oriyano.

4
00:00:16.740 --> 00:00:17.830
How are you doing, Sean?

5
00:00:17.830 --> 00:00:18.897
>> I'm doing pretty good,
how are you doing?

6
00:00:18.897 --> 00:00:19.860
>> I'm doing fantastic.

7
00:00:19.860 --> 00:00:23.566
Excited to get back into our Metasploit
episodes and in this one, Sean,

8
00:00:23.566 --> 00:00:27.240
we're gonna talk about some of
the different versions of Metasploit.

9
00:00:27.240 --> 00:00:29.851
Because if I go out there
to Rapid7's website,

10
00:00:29.851 --> 00:00:33.622
I know there's more than one option
I have to download this software.

11
00:00:33.622 --> 00:00:34.250
Right?

12
00:00:34.250 --> 00:00:39.570
>> Yeah, there's different versions,
definitely floating around out there, and

13
00:00:39.570 --> 00:00:45.260
it could get rather confusing if you start
just kinda looking around on your own.

14
00:00:45.260 --> 00:00:46.170
And so,

15
00:00:46.170 --> 00:00:51.280
to alleviate that we should talk about
the different versions that are out there.

16
00:00:51.280 --> 00:00:55.590
Really, there's only two that you're
ever gonna run into on a regular basis,

17
00:00:55.590 --> 00:00:58.810
but there are really four overall.

18
00:00:58.810 --> 00:01:01.400
So it is worth kind of just
throwing those all in there.

19
00:01:01.400 --> 00:01:04.150
But just to make sure
that no one gets lost and

20
00:01:04.150 --> 00:01:08.880
is like, which one do I use again and
the kinda scratching their head.

21
00:01:08.880 --> 00:01:14.320
We're gonna make sure we cover these
different versions and talk about why one

22
00:01:14.320 --> 00:01:19.350
over the other or
maybe better to say what one

23
00:01:19.350 --> 00:01:23.640
has that the other one doesn't, or
doesn't have that the other ones do have.

24
00:01:23.640 --> 00:01:27.970
So, that's what were
trying to really explore

25
00:01:27.970 --> 00:01:29.604
when we go through this whole thing.

26
00:01:29.604 --> 00:01:31.275
>> Okay.

27
00:01:31.275 --> 00:01:36.254
>> So for the metasploit versions that we
have, the two big ones that you're going

28
00:01:36.254 --> 00:01:39.780
to run into are the community and
the pro version.

29
00:01:39.780 --> 00:01:42.894
Also if we're gonna be doing it here,
it runs in the community version,

30
00:01:42.894 --> 00:01:44.340
that's what we're doing.

31
00:01:44.340 --> 00:01:46.270
That's what we're all sort of working on.

32
00:01:46.270 --> 00:01:50.640
The stuff you're gonna be doing in
Windows, if you decide to use Windows as

33
00:01:50.640 --> 00:01:56.390
your weapon of choice this week, that's
gonna be the community edition as well.

34
00:01:56.390 --> 00:02:00.055
And you'll know it's community
edition because if you paid for

35
00:02:00.055 --> 00:02:01.257
it, it's not the community edition.

36
00:02:01.257 --> 00:02:02.802
>> [LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH] [CROSSTALK] That's

37
00:02:02.802 --> 00:02:04.540
really the easy way to figure that out.

38
00:02:04.540 --> 00:02:06.745
>> Did I have to break out
my credit card or not?

39
00:02:06.745 --> 00:02:07.885
Oh, I must have got the community edition.

40
00:02:07.885 --> 00:02:10.748
>> Yeah, if you swiped the credit card,
that's not the community edition.

41
00:02:10.748 --> 00:02:15.720
So the community edition is
something that's freely available.

42
00:02:15.720 --> 00:02:19.010
And you get it from Rapid7.

43
00:02:20.070 --> 00:02:24.310
You can get the repositories from Linux.

44
00:02:24.310 --> 00:02:29.290
Just go ahead and do whatever in your
version of Linux to pull it down and

45
00:02:29.290 --> 00:02:30.350
install it.

46
00:02:30.350 --> 00:02:35.350
So that's the most commonly encountered
version that you're gonna see.

47
00:02:35.350 --> 00:02:37.360
And most people are actually
just fine with it.

48
00:02:37.360 --> 00:02:39.840
There are some areas
that are lacking in it.

49
00:02:39.840 --> 00:02:44.420
But for the most part,
unless you're one of the big boy develop.

50
00:02:44.420 --> 00:02:47.460
You're probably never,
ever gonna miss that stuff.

51
00:02:47.460 --> 00:02:52.010
It's just not something that's
gonna be on your radar.

52
00:02:52.010 --> 00:02:53.710
So that would be the community edition.

53
00:02:53.710 --> 00:02:56.850
And like I said,
you can get it from Rapid7 right now or

54
00:02:56.850 --> 00:03:00.230
through your Linux version.

55
00:03:00.230 --> 00:03:04.992
Then the pro version, the pro version
is the paid version, it's the big boy.

56
00:03:04.992 --> 00:03:08.320
It's got all the bells and
whistles that you can think of.

57
00:03:08.320 --> 00:03:10.500
It can do a lot of neat stuff.

58
00:03:10.500 --> 00:03:16.108
It allows you to do additional things
with modules and stuff like that.

59
00:03:16.108 --> 00:03:20.320
It's really ment for
enterprise level testing, so

60
00:03:20.320 --> 00:03:23.870
you're talking big, big, big projects.

61
00:03:23.870 --> 00:03:28.750
And in that context, when you talk about
big projects, we're specifically talking

62
00:03:28.750 --> 00:03:33.358
about being able to test, evaluate, and
remedy problems on a much quicker basis

63
00:03:33.358 --> 00:03:36.570
than we could with something
like a community edition.

64
00:03:36.570 --> 00:03:40.720
Community edition can very well be
used in an enterprise environment.

65
00:03:40.720 --> 00:03:43.820
There's actually absolutely
nothing saying it can't be.

66
00:03:43.820 --> 00:03:46.170
But it's not optimized for that.

67
00:03:46.170 --> 00:03:47.710
So if you in an Enterprise environment and

68
00:03:47.710 --> 00:03:50.455
you're kind of doing spot checks here and
there.

69
00:03:50.455 --> 00:03:53.450
Community edition might be just fine for
you, but

70
00:03:53.450 --> 00:03:59.270
the pro edition is something if
you have a lot of systems and

71
00:03:59.270 --> 00:04:01.830
software tests and
a lot of vulnerabilities to go over,

72
00:04:01.830 --> 00:04:07.340
then pro is gonna be worth the money,
cuz it will speed up that whole process.

73
00:04:07.340 --> 00:04:10.250
And there's another little
detail to it as well.

74
00:04:10.250 --> 00:04:15.395
Is, community edition, they say it's,
community edition is for

75
00:04:15.395 --> 00:04:18.940
non-commercial uses.

76
00:04:18.940 --> 00:04:21.850
They allow you to use it in educational
environments, so if you're doing it for

77
00:04:21.850 --> 00:04:25.760
training purposes, or using it for
stuff like we are, where we're not

78
00:04:25.760 --> 00:04:29.210
using it to develop software [LAUGH] or
make money off of, you're fine.

79
00:04:29.210 --> 00:04:33.730
But they expect that yes
if you're gonna be doing

80
00:04:33.730 --> 00:04:38.820
a lot of development and testing,
they expect you to move over to pro.

81
00:04:38.820 --> 00:04:43.674
And they're pretty easy going about that,
but you never know.

82
00:04:43.674 --> 00:04:47.035
But just for your own personal use,
for non-commercial use, for

83
00:04:47.035 --> 00:04:49.975
training education,
they are saying, yeah, go ahead,

84
00:04:49.975 --> 00:04:52.929
use community eddition,
it's perfectly fine for that.

85
00:04:52.929 --> 00:04:57.697
And so heck, we've been using Community
Edition in classrooms a lot for years, so

86
00:04:57.697 --> 00:05:00.421
most people if they've
ever used Metasploit,

87
00:05:00.421 --> 00:05:03.930
that's the one they've run
to is that specific version.

88
00:05:03.930 --> 00:05:09.090
But overall they both,
they really look the same.

89
00:05:09.090 --> 00:05:12.780
Now, in addition to those two versions
we have an Express version and

90
00:05:12.780 --> 00:05:15.280
a Metasploit Framework Edition.

91
00:05:15.280 --> 00:05:21.510
Those are kind of really kind
of scaled down versions and

92
00:05:21.510 --> 00:05:25.380
they're really not seen all that much but
they do exist out there.

93
00:05:25.380 --> 00:05:29.630
The express version is a really
trimmed down version of Metasploit,

94
00:05:29.630 --> 00:05:30.890
that's basically been put on a diet,

95
00:05:30.890 --> 00:05:35.560
it's very specific to certain things, has
very specific things on it and that's it.

96
00:05:35.560 --> 00:05:38.810
And then the framework is just
a small number of things.

97
00:05:38.810 --> 00:05:42.910
And it's commandline, that's really,
just everything's commandline.

98
00:05:42.910 --> 00:05:46.180
And that's all you're getting.

99
00:05:46.180 --> 00:05:49.640
>> If I want to develop a module
that's gonna work with Metasploit or

100
00:05:49.640 --> 00:05:51.690
something like that,
I might need the framework?

101
00:05:51.690 --> 00:05:55.930
>> Yeah, you could use the framework for
developing some basic modules with it.

102
00:05:55.930 --> 00:05:58.770
But I would say more than likely
most people are gonna just use

103
00:05:58.770 --> 00:05:59.590
the community or pro.

104
00:05:59.590 --> 00:06:02.723
They're probably never gonna
encounter the other two.

105
00:06:02.723 --> 00:06:06.712
For all intensive purposes having
said that there might be a number of

106
00:06:06.712 --> 00:06:10.033
people out here that have
actually used those versions.

107
00:06:10.033 --> 00:06:14.555
And at one point in time if you
go back before Rapid7 acquired

108
00:06:14.555 --> 00:06:18.540
the technology those were
a little more common.

109
00:06:18.540 --> 00:06:23.320
But for the most part now,
don't expect to see those.

110
00:06:23.320 --> 00:06:26.960
Expect to see community or pro and
then the line's drawn there.

111
00:06:26.960 --> 00:06:29.180
And just kind of hey whatever else
is over there, is over there.

112
00:06:29.180 --> 00:06:30.850
And we're just gonna ignore it.

113
00:06:30.850 --> 00:06:32.390
So and that makes it easier.

114
00:06:32.390 --> 00:06:35.230
That makes it a lot easier,
to tell you the truth.

115
00:06:35.230 --> 00:06:37.720
Because four different versions,

116
00:06:37.720 --> 00:06:41.600
and you've gotta learn the differences
between all four different versions.

117
00:06:41.600 --> 00:06:42.580
Why bother?

118
00:06:42.580 --> 00:06:45.065
>> You're starting to remind me of
Microsoft and their Windows flavors.

119
00:06:45.065 --> 00:06:48.625
[LAUGH]
>> Yeah, see, Rapid 7 was first.

120
00:06:48.625 --> 00:06:49.600
>> Right.

121
00:06:49.600 --> 00:06:52.240
>> But yeah, it's, just keep that in mind.

122
00:06:52.240 --> 00:06:58.310
Most of you are probably gonna just
use the Community Edition during your

123
00:06:58.310 --> 00:07:02.850
whole exploration using that sploit.

124
00:07:02.850 --> 00:07:07.389
I mean, heck, you might even use it
to do some of your basic pen testing.

125
00:07:07.389 --> 00:07:12.264
But remember if you're gonna be doing
really heavy duty commercial stuff and

126
00:07:12.264 --> 00:07:16.614
making some serious money off this,
then, yeah, they do put that,

127
00:07:16.614 --> 00:07:19.016
they want you to go to the pro version.

128
00:07:19.016 --> 00:07:19.991
>> Yeah, it's only right.

129
00:07:19.991 --> 00:07:21.809
Right?
If you're gonna go out there and

130
00:07:21.809 --> 00:07:23.298
bill people for your services and

131
00:07:23.298 --> 00:07:25.969
you're using Metasploit as
one of your major components.

132
00:07:25.969 --> 00:07:26.991
Gotta throw them a few bones.

133
00:07:26.991 --> 00:07:27.770
Right?

134
00:07:27.770 --> 00:07:30.350
And register your copy,
get that pro version.

135
00:07:30.350 --> 00:07:34.270
But for us, for studying while before
you become that famous bin tester,

136
00:07:34.270 --> 00:07:36.870
you can use that community addition for
free.

137
00:07:36.870 --> 00:07:38.120
And no problems, no harm, no foul.

138
00:07:38.120 --> 00:07:43.340
All right, so Sean, we've got our
version to pick, free for the most part.

139
00:07:43.340 --> 00:07:47.450
Unless we're gonna be making money off of
it or we need the extra performance in

140
00:07:47.450 --> 00:07:52.600
a large corporate environment,
then we move up into that pro version.

141
00:07:52.600 --> 00:07:54.030
What about installation?

142
00:07:54.030 --> 00:07:55.490
I know you said we could
run it on Windows,

143
00:07:55.490 --> 00:07:58.050
we could run it on Linux, even Unix.

144
00:07:58.050 --> 00:07:59.820
But any special considerations
they're gonna have?

145
00:07:59.820 --> 00:08:03.871
Like tons of memory or
fast hard drives, or-

146
00:08:03.871 --> 00:08:04.993
>> You know,

00:19:58.250 --> 00:19:59.300
When we look at it this way.

347
00:19:59.300 --> 00:20:02.360
When you look at stuff
like scanners in here.

348
00:20:02.360 --> 00:20:04.810
I mean, it's got all sorts of
different scanners loaded.

349
00:20:04.810 --> 00:20:08.988
It just says,
we'll drill down one more level on that.

350
00:20:08.988 --> 00:20:12.590
So it does make it a lot easier for you.

351
00:20:12.590 --> 00:20:18.430
There's our exploits,
organized by context.

352
00:20:18.430 --> 00:20:22.535
So pretty neat, but
that's not the only stuff that's here.

353
00:20:22.535 --> 00:20:26.280
I just always wanna say, but that's not
all, there's more stuff here, wait,

354
00:20:26.280 --> 00:20:27.350
[LAUGH] there's more.

355
00:20:27.350 --> 00:20:28.740
There's more stuff, go over here.

356
00:20:28.740 --> 00:20:34.610
I mean, you see over right next to it, off
to the right, you see the computer here,

357
00:20:34.610 --> 00:20:38.790
so I've got my IP address sitting there.

358
00:20:38.790 --> 00:20:42.720
Well, you can, as you start connecting to
remote hosts and start running different

00:20:42.720 --> 00:20:46.060
attacks, it can actually lay them out for

00:20:46.060 --> 00:20:49.120
are laid out to one another, and
how the connections are going.

361
00:20:49.120 --> 00:20:55.884
So another way of helping visualize what's
going on, so that's very valuable to have.

362
00:20:55.884 --> 00:20:57.626
And then, we've got,

363
00:20:57.626 --> 00:21:03.160
down at the bottom you have the regular
Metasploit console ready to go.

364
00:21:03.160 --> 00:21:10.360
So you've got everything right here,
ready to go and start interacting with.

365
00:21:10.360 --> 00:21:15.767
So someone's effectively created
why it is a very basic GUI.

366
00:21:15.767 --> 00:21:20.820
It is a GUI, nonetheless,
where we didn't have one before.

367
00:21:20.820 --> 00:21:25.420
So that's what you have, and
this guy actually had it,

368
00:21:25.420 --> 00:21:29.660
did this actually has,
this is Armitage, it's completely free.

369
00:21:29.660 --> 00:21:34.570
He does have a, something I
think it's called Cobalt Strike.

00:21:34.570 --> 00:21:35.731
So that's an awesome name.

371
00:21:35.731 --> 00:21:39.054
>> [LAUGH]
>> I'm gonna create something it would be

00:21:39.054 --> 00:21:40.676
called Cobalt Strike, I don't care.

373
00:21:40.676 --> 00:21:45.802
>> [LAUGH]
>> But he's got something called

374
00:21:45.802 --> 00:21:50.924
Colbat Strike which is like
the big boy super duper advanced

00:21:50.924 --> 00:21:56.765
version of this that can do extremely
wicked stuff that Armitage and

00:21:56.765 --> 00:21:59.855
Metasploit can't do on it's own.

00:21:59.855 --> 00:22:04.636
But that's like requires enterprise
licensing and all sorts of special

00:22:04.636 --> 00:22:09.803
training to use, most of us won't need

00:22:09.803 --> 00:22:13.408
testing across the board all
sorts of applications and

380
00:22:13.408 --> 00:22:16.491
all sorts of exotic and
unique environments.

381
00:22:16.491 --> 00:22:22.005
You'll probably never need that,
but this is what Armitage is.

382
00:22:22.005 --> 00:22:26.817
If you need to exit out of Armitage
all you gonna do is just go

just click Close.

384
00:22:30.950 --> 00:22:33.900
It should take you right back

385

Do not go up to the X at the upper
right corner and click like that.

386
00:22:37.957 --> 00:22:40.920
That could very well close all of
your console and everything out.

387
00:22:40.920 --> 00:22:43.770
You'd have to open up the console and

388
00:22:43.770 --> 00:22:46.118
>> Yeah, wait for
it all to reload, so yeah.

389
00:22:46.118 --> 00:22:50.140
>> Yeah, I mean minor thing,
minor inconvenience I guess.

390
00:22:50.140 --> 00:22:55.040
But it's something that you can

00:22:55.040 --> 00:22:57.780
of that whole process happening there.

392
00:22:57.780 --> 00:22:58.790
>> Nice.

393
00:22:58.790 --> 00:22:59.530
There's a few different ways.

394
00:22:59.530 --> 00:23:01.480
Then we can interface with Metasploit.

395
00:23:01.480 --> 00:23:04.470
We've got our standard shell our console.

396
00:23:04.470 --> 00:23:08.103
We've got the CLI which is being
depreciated, so that one is kind of

00:23:08.103 --> 00:23:12.144
going away on us, and we've go Armitage,
Armitage I guess we should say.

398
00:23:12.144 --> 00:23:12.877
>> Everyone wants, yeah.

399
00:23:12.877 --> 00:23:16.526
>> [LAUGH] Nice that somebody has
taken the time to develop that and

00:23:16.526 --> 00:23:19.622
give those people had that
fear of the command line.

401
00:23:19.622 --> 00:23:23.420
Maybe a good starting point, get them

402
00:23:23.420 --> 00:23:28.052
Gonna get that GUI command line
combination going on in there and

403
00:23:28.052 --> 00:23:32.616
give them a chance to ease on
into that command line interface.

404
00:23:32.616 --> 00:23:37.520
>> Yeah, it really is and there's nothing
saying that if you're an advanced user

405

that you can't use Armitage just
to make it easier on yourself.

406
00:23:41.489 --> 00:23:45.140
I have no problem with people
making it easier on them self.

407
00:23:45.140 --> 00:23:47.321
I have had people over the years ask me,
it's like well,

408
00:23:47.321 --> 00:23:48.600
how did you learn all that stuff.

409
00:23:48.600 --> 00:23:49.296
You must be really smart.

410
00:23:49.296 --> 00:23:50.613
It's like No, I'm freaking lazy,

411
00:23:50.613 --> 00:23:52.570
cuz I don't want to do a bunch
of extra work, you know.

412
00:23:52.570 --> 00:23:53.824
I'm going to find
the easiest way to do it.

413
00:23:53.824 --> 00:23:55.350
Path of least resistance.

414
00:23:55.350 --> 00:23:56.660
You know that's why I do this stuff.

415
00:23:56.660 --> 00:23:58.500
It has nothing to do with intelligence.

416
00:23:58.500 --> 00:24:03.785
So, that's,
I have no problem with someone using that.

417
00:24:03.785 --> 00:24:08.815
Just make sure you understand what's

00:24:08.815 --> 00:24:14.405

00:24:14.405 --> 00:24:21.095
If you don't have that Armitage, you won't

00:24:21.095 --> 00:24:27.210
So, you know, just be prepared for

421
00:24:27.210 --> 00:24:32.890
the guy that creates Armitage, he's pretty

He's puts it out there pretty straight

You can email him and he usually gets back

424
00:24:43.950 --> 00:24:45.960
And he's pretty knowledgeable.

He also is one of the ones

that doesn't really want to

427
00:24:55.190 --> 00:24:56.810
>> [LAUGH]
>> He's like, and he's nice about it.

He's like, yeah, you can do stuff

429
00:25:00.560 --> 00:25:04.260
You know, so just FYI.

430
00:25:04.260 --> 00:25:07.140
If you're going to be doing that.

431

So the thing I want to make sure

00:25:12.240 --> 00:25:16.325
Is just remember that,
cuz this is going to come up big later on,

is you're not just limited

You have the tools in Metasploit,

435
00:25:23.265 --> 00:25:27.765
all that, but you can also access that

436
00:25:27.765 --> 00:25:31.245
So if you're using Kali,
we went through and

things like FPing, and HPing,
and, and map all those things.

Pretty much every last one of those can

00:25:45.970 --> 00:25:51.080
without exiting Metasploit,

Just imagine if you go through the stuff

00:25:58.830 --> 00:26:00.450
And then you get comfortable

You've just bumped up your skills and
your power tremendously, so

445
00:26:06.930 --> 00:26:09.750
don't forget that,
cuz we will be doing that here.

446
00:26:09.750 --> 00:26:14.880
We will be stringing both of those
together to get that association in your

00:26:14.880 --> 00:26:15.920
head ready to go.

448
00:26:15.920 --> 00:26:17.230
>> Fantastic, all right.

449
00:26:17.230 --> 00:26:18.600
A lot of great information there.

450
00:26:18.600 --> 00:26:21.980
We're getting closer and
closer to seeing Metasploit in action.

451
00:26:21.980 --> 00:26:24.210
But again,
we gotta learn our way around there.

452
00:26:24.210 --> 00:26:26.980
We saw a few different interfaces
this time and you know,

453
00:26:26.980 --> 00:26:29.700
how we can interact with Metasploit and
work with it.

454
00:26:29.700 --> 00:26:32.780
So good information, Sean,
looking at our clock, it's about time for

455
00:26:32.780 --> 00:26:34.010
us to call this one a wrap.

456
00:26:34.010 --> 00:26:37.120
So I think that's what we'll do,
but make sure you come back.

457
00:26:37.120 --> 00:26:40.410
We've got more episodes on
Metasploit coming your way.

458
00:26:40.410 --> 00:26:43.720
But for now, signing off for

00:26:43.720 --> 00:26:44.440
>> And I'm Sean Oriyano.

460
00:26:44.440 --> 00:26:46.532

461

8

Another exciting episode coming

Continuing on with our Metasploit

we're gonna take another look and

Now we wanna look at something

some utilities that

>> Yeah and
these are really utilities that are,

I kinda wanna give you an idea that these

This is really for those of you that

Which are things that we're gonna

just also to throw in

Another reason even if you haven't

products like this, Open Source and

all that kinda gets just smeared

In fact, if you go look at several of

00:01:49.020 --> 00:01:50.760
That utility doesn't exist anymore.

33

You type it in, and

00:01:57.940 --> 00:01:58.930
That's frustrating.

37
00:01:58.930 --> 00:01:59.610
>> Yeah.
And so,

38
00:01:59.610 --> 00:02:01.830
we're trying to avoid you
pulling your hair out and

getting frustrated and
going, what the heck?

40
00:02:04.260 --> 00:02:05.270
Why isn't this working?

41

Why was it working on screen,

00:02:07.360 --> 00:02:10.070
why is it working one way on screen

43
00:02:10.070 --> 00:02:12.780
This book is brand new,

44
00:02:12.780 --> 00:02:15.350
Well, book isn't using new

45
00:02:15.350 --> 00:02:19.530
And so we want to make sure that, just in

00:02:19.530 --> 00:02:23.750
if you're looking at documentation that
might be just a little bit out of date,

47
00:02:23.750 --> 00:02:28.170
that you're not caught in a trap there and

00:02:31.360 --> 00:02:32.610
We definetly do not want that.

50
00:02:32.610 --> 00:02:35.200
It's a great product, powerful product.

51
00:02:35.200 --> 00:02:38.560
And something you should be using

52
00:02:38.560 --> 00:02:43.950
So let's avoid those little pitfalls and
talk about these utilities.

53
00:02:43.950 --> 00:02:45.800
And talk about what replaced them.

00:02:45.800 --> 00:02:47.180
And what they do.

55
00:02:47.180 --> 00:02:48.210
>> Cool.

56
00:02:48.210 --> 00:02:49.200
All right well let's take a look.

57
00:02:49.200 --> 00:02:50.150
Where do we start?

58
00:02:50.150 --> 00:02:53.050
What's the first one that
they've gotten rid of us on us?

59
00:02:53.050 --> 00:02:56.480
>> The first one we have that they've
actually replaced with something else is

60
00:02:56.480 --> 00:02:58.610
one called MSF Payload.

61
00:02:58.610 --> 00:03:03.280
What this one does is this one is
something that's designed to allow you to

62
00:03:03.280 --> 00:03:08.530
create payloads to drop off on a system.

63
00:03:08.530 --> 00:03:11.330
And you're gonna use
different development tools.

64
00:03:11.330 --> 00:03:17.065
You can use things like Visual Basic,
C++, stuff like that to develop it.

65
00:03:17.065 --> 00:03:19.755
And this would allow you
to take those things and

66
00:03:19.755 --> 00:03:24.555

the Metasploit environment.

67
00:03:24.555 --> 00:03:29.165
And so, it's a cool thing to have that
because if you're gonna be developing

68
00:03:29.165 --> 00:03:33.475
this, or working with this and developing,
you kinda need something like that.

69
00:03:33.475 --> 00:03:35.695
And so they went through and
they kinda just axed that.

70
00:03:35.695 --> 00:03:38.705
It wasn't because they're trying to
close the product off or anything.

71
00:03:38.705 --> 00:03:43.660
What they did is they actually
replaced it with another utility and

72
00:03:43.660 --> 00:03:46.970
actually they have it replaced
several things with this utility.

73
00:03:46.970 --> 00:03:50.348
There's one called MSF,
the much more cool sounding, by the way,

74
00:03:50.348 --> 00:03:51.419
>> [LAUGH]

75
00:03:51.419 --> 00:03:52.380
>> MSF venom.

76
00:03:52.380 --> 00:03:55.210
That's the name of the new tool.

77
00:03:55.210 --> 00:03:58.266
>> Venom.
>> Yeah, I love that.

78
00:03:58.266 --> 00:04:01.429
So it's scary but
that's what they went through,

79
00:04:01.429 --> 00:04:06.005
is they replaced MSF payload,
with MSF Venom, so you can do everything.

80
00:04:06.005 --> 00:04:12.870
You could do in MSF Payload with the Venom
utility and not have any problem, okay.

81
00:04:12.870 --> 00:04:14.560
>> Nice.
>> Now obviously there's some new

82
00:04:14.560 --> 00:04:17.380
stuff added in there, and
some other things like that,

83
00:04:17.380 --> 00:04:19.450
if you do wanna develop your own exploits.

84
00:04:20.660 --> 00:04:23.450
And if you wanna develop your own exploits
that's gonna require, like I said,

85
00:04:23.450 --> 00:04:26.350
all sorts of programming and
knowledge like that.

86
00:04:26.350 --> 00:04:28.640
That's not going to be stuff that we're
[LAUGH] really going to worry about

87
00:04:28.640 --> 00:04:32.480
talking about in here because can't
talk about a, it's no good for

88
00:04:32.480 --> 00:04:35.350
us to talk about exploits
anywhere in this whole coverage

89
00:04:35.350 --> 00:04:39.610
of Metasploit unless you know all those
programming skills coming in, so.

90
00:04:39.610 --> 00:04:43.530
Once you've got those skills though
you can figure out an exploit

91
00:04:43.530 --> 00:04:45.410
pretty quickly, you know, so.

92
00:04:45.410 --> 00:04:49.140
Like in an afternoon, I've heard people
create exploits in an afternoon.

93
00:04:49.140 --> 00:04:51.860
After they know how Metasploit works,
they're a software developer,

94
00:04:51.860 --> 00:04:54.520
just type something in,
and they're firing it off.

95
00:04:54.520 --> 00:04:58.100
So that's the cool thing about that.

96
00:04:58.100 --> 00:05:01.550
>> So they didn't take our capability away
to use other products to develop these,

97
00:05:01.550 --> 00:05:04.510
it just changed the tool we're gonna
use then to bring those into our

98
00:05:04.510 --> 00:05:05.810
Metasploit environment.

99
00:05:05.810 --> 00:05:09.560
Yeah, it's as Metasploit has evolved and

100
00:05:09.560 --> 00:05:14.340
metamorphasized over the years its,
they've

101
00:05:14.340 --> 00:05:19.130
always allowed you to develop your own
exploits but it's a question of just now.

102
00:05:20.660 --> 00:05:24.370
Some of the tools may have changed or
become more powerful.

103
00:05:24.370 --> 00:05:29.450
I mean even Metasploit itself at one point
was developed with a totally different

104
00:05:29.450 --> 00:05:30.890
programming language, and

105
00:05:30.890 --> 00:05:35.420
now it was basically rearchitected from
the ground up so it's all done in Ruby.

106
00:05:35.420 --> 00:05:41.130
So that required [LAUGH] some changes.

107
00:05:41.130 --> 00:05:47.380
You have tools like this also reflecting
those changes and giving you more power.

108
00:05:47.380 --> 00:05:51.420
And they very clearly have
documented how to create exploits so

109
00:05:51.420 --> 00:05:53.480
this would be one of
the utilities that you'd use.

And that's the name of the game is to

If you don't get a good complete picture,

What are some of the tools that

It's something that we said, again, in an

And you don't have to do anything funky

It's right there ready for you to go.

00:02:54.190 --> 00:02:58.845
So that's what we're gonna focus on is

00:02:58.845 --> 00:03:04.023
we've seen before, but we're gonna use

And I also think it's something that

grabs and hit some of those IP addresses.

279
00:16:56.790 --> 00:16:57.880
Like the name servers.

280
00:16:57.880 --> 00:16:59.090
You get the IP address and

281
00:16:59.090 --> 00:17:03.460
hit it, because you might be able to tell
what operating system that's running on.

282
00:17:03.460 --> 00:17:10.980
And there's tools directly in
Metasploit that will hit DNS servers.

283
00:17:10.980 --> 00:17:13.090
You might look at getting the IP address.

284
00:17:13.090 --> 00:17:16.580
We see an IP address there for
a mail server.

285
00:17:16.580 --> 00:17:19.800
That looks like it's hosted
by Microsoft with that.

286
00:17:19.800 --> 00:17:24.530
Well, we could hit that and
figure out, see if we could figure out

287
00:17:24.530 --> 00:17:29.439
what operating system and
maybe what mail server they're using.

288
00:17:30.550 --> 00:17:32.540
Probably notes, right?

289
00:17:32.540 --> 00:17:33.740
No.
>> [LAUGH] I'm sure.

290
00:17:33.740 --> 00:17:35.400
>> Yeah, that's what they're doing.

291
00:17:35.400 --> 00:17:37.060
It's their trick.

292
00:17:37.060 --> 00:17:40.610
So we could hit that IP address and

293
00:17:40.610 --> 00:17:44.110
figure out presumably what
version exchange they're running.

294
00:17:44.110 --> 00:17:48.960
And there are exploits for that too, so

295
00:17:48.960 --> 00:17:53.320
that's where you gotta look a little
deeper now and take some time.

296
00:17:53.320 --> 00:18:00.100
You know how to do that, so we're not
gonna take a ton of time doing that.

297
00:18:00.100 --> 00:18:02.080
You should already know how to do that.

298
00:18:02.080 --> 00:18:03.620
If you're not, CEH has that covered.

299
00:18:03.620 --> 00:18:06.660
So we'll let you go back there to
the intelligence gathering and

300
00:18:06.660 --> 00:18:11.670
reconnaissance stuff to crystallize
that and get that clear for you.

301
00:18:13.450 --> 00:18:17.970
So we're doing not too bad so far.

302
00:18:17.970 --> 00:18:23.000
We're getting good stuff and we can go
even further with this if you wanted.

303
00:18:23.000 --> 00:18:28.040
And I haven't even opened up
other stuff like Netcraft.

304
00:18:28.040 --> 00:18:29.060
I haven't opened up that.

305
00:18:29.060 --> 00:18:32.050
I haven't opened up these other utilities.

306
00:18:32.050 --> 00:18:34.570
To, take it to that level.

307
00:18:34.570 --> 00:18:38.170
There's nothing saying you couldn't,
I just haven't done that.

308
00:18:38.170 --> 00:18:44.660
You know so, there's those things
actually available to you.

309
00:18:44.660 --> 00:18:47.560
>> A lot of good information so far.

310
00:18:47.560 --> 00:18:49.570
We've just used a couple of those.

311
00:18:49.570 --> 00:18:55.790
>> And there, just an FYI we also have
some other, just to put it out there.

312
00:18:55.790 --> 00:18:59.280
I'm not I got kind of fat
fingers a couple times,

313
00:18:59.280 --> 00:19:01.400
that's why I'm getting
a lot of stuff in here.

314
00:19:01.400 --> 00:19:05.440
We could do one for
what was mentioned in the Kali class,

315
00:19:05.440 --> 00:19:08.950
do the load balancing discovery.

316
00:19:08.950 --> 00:19:12.790
We're doing our probing around hit Enter,
and see what it pops up and says oh yeah,

317
00:19:12.790 --> 00:19:19.740
there's load balancing in place, or
not in place as the case may be.

318
00:19:19.740 --> 00:19:24.870
So that's something that we're looking
in there and we're seeing that,

319
00:19:24.870 --> 00:19:29.690
it's telling us
the information that it found.

320
00:19:29.690 --> 00:19:31.400
I found that kind of interesting.

321
00:19:31.400 --> 00:19:33.250
I did put Microsoft, right?

322
00:19:33.250 --> 00:19:34.070
It says Apache.

323
00:19:35.950 --> 00:19:37.100
Yeah.
Interesting.

324
00:19:37.100 --> 00:19:39.000
>> Microsoft has seen the light.

325
00:19:39.000 --> 00:19:44.680
>> They're changing [LAUGH]
>> So that could be.

326
00:19:44.680 --> 00:19:52.780
This is actually a good learning thing
here because we might have a situation.

327
00:19:52.780 --> 00:19:55.380
I mean the guy who writes this tool you
can kind of see a little bit of him in

328
00:19:55.380 --> 00:19:56.670
the upper right.

329
00:19:56.670 --> 00:19:59.610
He says it might give false positives and
stuff.

330
00:19:59.610 --> 00:20:03.700
So he's telling you yeah,
he's well aware that this thing is,

331
00:20:03.700 --> 00:20:06.740
he wrote it and
he's still kinda playing with it.

332
00:20:06.740 --> 00:20:09.670
And possibly it's gonna give
you bogus information, so

333
00:20:09.670 --> 00:20:13.810
you might not wanna entirely
rely on what's on here.

334
00:20:13.810 --> 00:20:17.850
And anybody that was watching our Kali
stuff last week knows we ran the exact

335
00:20:17.850 --> 00:20:21.380
same tool, and it did say that
there was load balancing there.

336
00:20:21.380 --> 00:20:23.710
And we know there's load balancing there.

337
00:20:23.710 --> 00:20:24.810
We've checked that already.

338
00:20:24.810 --> 00:20:26.530
So, why is this doing it?

339
00:20:26.530 --> 00:20:28.840
Well, this could be,
when we look at Apache,

340
00:20:28.840 --> 00:20:32.540
Apache's typically associated with
the Unix / Linux side of the house.

341
00:20:32.540 --> 00:20:34.640
Well, if you remember from way back,

342
00:20:34.640 --> 00:20:39.850
when we did our Netcraft stuff, we saw
that it said that there was Linux and

343
00:20:39.850 --> 00:20:45.050
then there was IAS running on top of it
and we said that can't exist that way.

344
00:20:45.050 --> 00:20:47.850
So we determined that there was a load
balancer sitting in front of it, and

345
00:20:47.850 --> 00:20:51.840
then there was the Windows system behind
that with all these things on top of it,

346
00:20:51.840 --> 00:20:53.350
that's probably what's picking up.

347
00:20:53.350 --> 00:20:57.580
It's probably going out directly,
and hitting that instead.

348
00:20:57.580 --> 00:21:04.960
And it's IDed that aspect of it,
hasn't IDed the stuff behind it.

349
00:21:04.960 --> 00:21:07.420
>> And we've mentioned a couple times
in a few of our different classes,

350
00:21:07.420 --> 00:21:11.070
we talk about trust to verify
>> Use more than one tool if you got it,

351
00:21:11.070 --> 00:21:15.231
don't assume everything's
always gonna be 100% correct.

352
00:21:15.231 --> 00:21:17.970
>> Yeah, it's always,
always, always that way.

353
00:21:17.970 --> 00:21:21.140
Don't just run your favorite tool and

354
00:21:21.140 --> 00:21:25.120
go oh, well that's dead on,
that' exactly what I wanna see.

355
00:21:26.320 --> 00:21:27.440
>> That can hurt you.

356
00:21:27.440 --> 00:21:30.220
Especially with that mindset,
that's exactly what I wanna see,

357
00:21:30.220 --> 00:21:33.220
also you had a preconceived
idea what you should see?

358
00:21:33.220 --> 00:21:38.770
So you're gonna mold your evidence
around that, so the other way around,

359
00:21:38.770 --> 00:21:42.020
so yeah,
just be careful with this type of stuff.

360
00:21:42.020 --> 00:21:47.099
So, but, yeah, we've already seen
a couple of things here that we can just

361
00:21:49.750 --> 00:21:53.650
drop right out of the Metasploit
environment temporarily,

362
00:21:53.650 --> 00:21:56.850
run those commands, and
we can go right back in when we exit it.

363
00:21:56.850 --> 00:21:59.660
So we're not fully
exiting that environment.

364
00:21:59.660 --> 00:22:05.620
We could be just porting this stuff
over and doing our whole deal.

365
00:22:05.620 --> 00:22:09.180
And we're not limited to just those tools.

366
00:22:09.180 --> 00:22:13.560
Like I said,
it's really anything and in our Kali

367
00:22:14.680 --> 00:22:18.390
exploration, we saw tools for
doing all sorts of stuff.

368
00:22:18.390 --> 00:22:23.220
Pulling meta data and
user information and doing all of that.

369
00:22:23.220 --> 00:22:29.040
So you could potentially be bringing a lot
of open source stuff right over here

370
00:22:29.040 --> 00:22:33.670
into Metasploit and
be doing further things with it.

371
00:22:33.670 --> 00:22:35.230
We just haven't got there.

372
00:22:35.230 --> 00:22:37.930
it's like we were just talking
about the fact that you can

373
00:22:37.930 --> 00:22:41.900
do this open source intelligence
gathering quite easily with it.

374
00:22:41.900 --> 00:22:45.750
So that's what we want to take out of
it is that you can run these tools.

375
00:22:45.750 --> 00:22:50.020
Again, if it says when you run a tool
inside of here saying unknown command or

376
00:22:50.020 --> 00:22:50.950
something.

377
00:22:50.950 --> 00:22:52.710
If you typed it right and
all that's correct,

378
00:22:52.710 --> 00:22:55.150
then it's probably not on your system,
and it knows it.

379
00:22:55.150 --> 00:22:57.480
It's not gonna say oh yeah,
I'll go download it.

380
00:22:57.480 --> 00:23:00.780
It's gonna say I don't know what's
wrong here, but I can't find it.

381
00:23:00.780 --> 00:23:03.100
You go solve it and ask me again.

382
00:23:03.100 --> 00:23:05.060
>> So
Metasploit gives us a nice interface.

383
00:23:05.060 --> 00:23:07.760
A way to kind of run it all
from that one location and

384
00:23:07.760 --> 00:23:11.240
even at some point start putting
it in this common database

385
00:23:11.240 --> 00:23:14.450
to keep track of our project, but
you still have to have the tool.

386
00:23:14.450 --> 00:23:16.590
Metasploit doesn't give
you all these tools.

387
00:23:16.590 --> 00:23:20.670
It has to be there on your system in
order for Metasploit to access it.

388
00:23:20.670 --> 00:23:21.830
>> Yeah, exactly.

389
00:23:21.830 --> 00:23:25.820
If it's not there,
you won't be able to access it, period.

390
00:23:25.820 --> 00:23:31.170
So be very, very cautious with that.

391
00:23:31.170 --> 00:23:31.770
>> Very good, Sean.

392
00:23:31.770 --> 00:23:34.160
Again, a lot of great information here.

393
00:23:34.160 --> 00:23:36.620
Passive intelligence gathering,
going out and

394
00:23:36.620 --> 00:23:40.050
finding information that's readily
available through public means.

395
00:23:40.050 --> 00:23:41.370
We didn't break into anything,

396
00:23:41.370 --> 00:23:43.770
we're not stealing anything,
we're not cracking passwords yet.

397
00:23:43.770 --> 00:23:45.170
We're checking who is databases,

398
00:23:45.170 --> 00:23:48.760
we're looking at DNS information
here at the registrars, we could

399
00:23:48.760 --> 00:23:52.940
possibly be looking at I'm assuming
company websites and places like that.

400
00:23:52.940 --> 00:23:56.890
We've talked about other ways to do this
passive intelligence gathering in other

401
00:23:56.890 --> 00:23:58.050
shows.

402
00:23:58.050 --> 00:24:02.015
Social media, all that great stuff,
lot of Information out there.

403
00:24:02.015 --> 00:24:05.995
And it lets us start painting a picture
of our target, of what it is that we're

404
00:24:05.995 --> 00:24:09.885
trying to either test or attack, or
whatever it is we're trying to do.

405
00:24:09.885 --> 00:24:12.705
So anything else you want to
throw in here Sean on the passive

406
00:24:12.705 --> 00:24:14.275
intelligence gathering?

407
00:24:14.275 --> 00:24:18.035
>> You know,
I like what you just said about it.

408
00:24:18.035 --> 00:24:22.636
When you're saying it about that we have
all these different information sources

409
00:24:22.636 --> 00:24:24.510
and places we can get stuff from.

410
00:24:24.510 --> 00:24:30.852
Just kinda look at and think about what
you've got sitting on your desktop,

411
00:24:30.852 --> 00:24:35.328
if you're virtualizing Kali
with Metasploit in it.

412
00:24:37.070 --> 00:24:40.930
All the tools you need to
gather information are-

413
00:24:40.930 --> 00:24:42.460
there's just a tremendous amount.

414
00:24:42.460 --> 00:24:47.070
We said there was like 300, I actually
read, there are they said over 400.

415
00:24:47.070 --> 00:24:49.040
So we were off by a little bit.

416
00:24:49.040 --> 00:24:50.380
And whatever.

417
00:24:50.380 --> 00:24:55.170
But you've got over 400 tools in KALI.

418
00:24:55.170 --> 00:24:58.520
And that's not Including the full
capabilities of Metasploit.

419
00:24:58.520 --> 00:25:00.880
Metasploit's just, oh,
Metasploit's in there.

420
00:25:00.880 --> 00:25:04.200
Well Metasploit's not one tool,
it's a whole other

421
00:25:04.200 --> 00:25:09.020
can of worms you're opening that has
that additional levels of power.

422
00:25:09.020 --> 00:25:14.290
So when you get down to
it there could be 1,000

423
00:25:14.290 --> 00:25:18.880
tools plus that you have in Kali, when
you combine Metasploit and Kali together.

424
00:25:18.880 --> 00:25:21.440
I mean so that translates to just so

425
00:25:21.440 --> 00:25:26.690
much raw power sitting at your
desktop getting ready for

426
00:25:26.690 --> 00:25:31.320
you to use, that it's kinda frightening
in a way what you could do with it.

427
00:25:31.320 --> 00:25:34.450
And we haven't even gotten to the nasty
stuff yet we can do with this.

428
00:25:34.450 --> 00:25:35.140
>> Frightening,

429
00:25:35.140 --> 00:25:39.390
exhilarating I guess it just depends on
which way you wanna look at it so [LAUGH].

430
00:25:39.390 --> 00:25:41.020
All right, so Sean I'll tell you what,

431
00:25:41.020 --> 00:25:43.600
it's about time to wrap
this episode up so.

00:25:43.600 --> 00:25:46.130
Wanna thank everybody for tuning in and

>> And I'm Sean Oriyano.

00:25:50.680 --> 00:25:52.602

episodes.title: Active Intelligence Gathering
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.788
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:10.788 --> 00:00:14.080
Hello and
welcome to another episode of ITProTV.

3
00:00:14.080 --> 00:00:17.030
I'm your host, Mike Rodrick and
with me today is Mr Sean Oriyano.

4
00:00:17.030 --> 00:00:18.200
How are you doing, Sean?

5
00:00:18.200 --> 00:00:19.020
>> I'm doing pretty good.

6
00:00:19.020 --> 00:00:19.940
>> How are you doing?

7
00:00:19.940 --> 00:00:21.030
>> I'm doing fantastic.

8
00:00:21.030 --> 00:00:23.850
We've got another exciting episode
coming your way here at ITProTV.

9
00:00:23.850 --> 00:00:27.920
We're continuing on with
our Metasploit series.

10
00:00:27.920 --> 00:00:31.500
And in this episode, Sean, we're gonna
focus on active intelligence gathering.

11
00:00:31.500 --> 00:00:35.570
I know in a a previous episode we talked
about passive intelligence gathering.

12
00:00:35.570 --> 00:00:37.870
So if you haven't seen that one,
make sure you go and watch that one.

13
00:00:37.870 --> 00:00:41.440
And now we're gonna switch gears and
do a little active intelligence gathering.

14
00:00:41.440 --> 00:00:42.310
What's the big difference,

15
00:00:42.310 --> 00:00:45.770
Sean, between passive and active before
we dive into all these cool tools?

16
00:00:46.870 --> 00:00:51.340
>> Well, the real difference between
the two is the fact that when you're doing

17
00:00:51.340 --> 00:00:57.360
passive you are doing as little possible
engagement with the system as you can.

18
00:00:57.360 --> 00:00:57.923
And in fact,

19
00:00:57.923 --> 00:01:01.167
when I say as little as possible,
theoretically shouldn't be doing any.

20
00:01:01.167 --> 00:01:04.535
>> [LAUGH]
>> But we do find if you look back at some

21
00:01:04.535 --> 00:01:10.638
of the techniques we've used over our
previous journeys through PIN testing,

22
00:01:10.638 --> 00:01:16.645
we found out that, yeah, there are some
cases where you do very very minimal,

23
00:01:16.645 --> 00:01:22.777
but not enough to really increase your
chances of getting caught all that much.

24
00:01:22.777 --> 00:01:27.987
Now when you go over to active you
are firing probes at the system or

25
00:01:27.987 --> 00:01:30.510
systems as the case may be.

26
00:01:30.510 --> 00:01:36.740
Really looking for
that information to see what you can get.

27
00:01:36.740 --> 00:01:43.050
It could be you're looking to pull ranges
of the systems that are up or down.

28
00:01:43.050 --> 00:01:46.500
It could be that you're trying to
get lists of ports that are open.

29
00:01:46.500 --> 00:01:49.520
You could possibly start moving into that,
but

30
00:01:49.520 --> 00:01:52.270
there's a number of things but
actively means yes,

31
00:01:52.270 --> 00:01:56.480
you are engaging in the system you are
doing much more to make yourself visible

32
00:01:56.480 --> 00:02:00.290
but information may be more accurate but
you do pay for that at a price.

33
00:02:01.460 --> 00:02:03.460
So that's the big
difference between the two.

34
00:02:03.460 --> 00:02:07.470
>> So in our passive phase we were
gathering things like IP address ranges,

35
00:02:07.470 --> 00:02:09.930
DNS names that were registered.

36
00:02:09.930 --> 00:02:13.830
Going into these public sources of
information that anybody can go get,

37
00:02:13.830 --> 00:02:17.100
so we weren't raising any flags or setting
off any alarms or anything like that.

38
00:02:17.100 --> 00:02:19.000
Now we're going to take that information,

39
00:02:19.000 --> 00:02:21.870
like those IP address ranges,
try to find their live host.

40
00:02:21.870 --> 00:02:24.640
But to do that,
we've got to talk to their network.

41
00:02:24.640 --> 00:02:28.680
So now, with the active phase,
we are as you say,

42
00:02:28.680 --> 00:02:32.610
engaging the enemy here which is
obviously gonna increase our chances for

43
00:02:32.610 --> 00:02:36.160
detection or setting off alarms and
things like that.

44
00:02:36.160 --> 00:02:40.340
But it is our next step as
we progress into this test.

45
00:02:40.340 --> 00:02:41.340
>> Yeah.
Absolutely.

46
00:02:41.340 --> 00:02:46.510
So that's what we gotta do is we gotta
start gaining information from that

47
00:02:46.510 --> 00:02:51.590
target and so
you've got plenty of tools to do that and

48
00:02:51.590 --> 00:02:57.840
we've seen lots of tools in the past that
we can use to do that active engagement.

49
00:02:57.840 --> 00:03:01.936
We can look at some of those tools again
before we start moving into the way

50
00:03:01.936 --> 00:03:04.702
what NMAPS brings to
the table in this category.

51
00:03:04.702 --> 00:03:08.985
Because NMAP does have
some stuff outside of what

52
00:03:08.985 --> 00:03:13.168
the regular tools in Kali or
whatever would do.

53
00:03:13.168 --> 00:03:17.798
It has its own stuff that it can
do additional levels of tests,

54
00:03:17.798 --> 00:03:19.940
which is quite neat.

55
00:03:19.940 --> 00:03:24.855
So, what we need to kinda do a compare and
contrast here I guess between the two.

56
00:03:24.855 --> 00:03:27.870
>> There's a lot of this similar
to our passive where we're

57
00:03:27.870 --> 00:03:31.460
taking tools that we've already seen or
maybe learned to use and

58
00:03:31.460 --> 00:03:34.370
just using them through
the Metasploit interface?

59
00:03:34.370 --> 00:03:34.920
>> Yes.

60
00:03:34.920 --> 00:03:38.390
That's really what it is, is that you're
using a lot of this stuff at this point

61
00:03:38.390 --> 00:03:41.080
through the Metasploit interface.

62
00:03:41.080 --> 00:03:43.780
But we're gonna start discussing

63
00:03:43.780 --> 00:03:48.340
how some of this stuff can be
integrated directly into the database.

64
00:03:48.340 --> 00:03:51.620
We're still not at the point where
we're gonna put it into the database,

65
00:03:51.620 --> 00:03:56.030
because we're going to do some set
up there before we get to that.

66
00:03:56.030 --> 00:03:57.598
But get the tools.

67
00:03:57.598 --> 00:04:01.730
Make sure that we're
getting the same nice,

68
00:04:01.730 --> 00:04:04.430
good information that we
would expect out of them.

69
00:04:04.430 --> 00:04:09.280

00:16:14.541 --> 00:16:16.216
>> [LAUGH]
>> Cuz you know what, no offense,

>> I've done it, and

you're gonna do it too.

So just remember that.

It's gonna save you a lot of pain and

had to keep going, [SOUND] MSF console.

00:16:31.407 --> 00:16:35.650
>> [LAUGH]
>> No more of that.

Metasploit being that outer shell, or

of the tool, then you're getting deeper,

303
00:16:51.680 --> 00:16:53.540
And it's like,
you wanna take one step back,

304
00:16:53.540 --> 00:16:56.280
you don't wanna leave the tool entirely.

305
00:16:56.280 --> 00:16:59.590
So maybe if we can think of that, that
will help us remember that back command.

306
00:16:59.590 --> 00:17:03.350
>> Yeah,
that's not a bad analogy at all is that,

307
00:17:03.350 --> 00:17:08.810
you only wanna go back a certain step or
only wanna do certain things.

308
00:17:08.810 --> 00:17:13.381
This is a great command
to have in your toolkit,

309
00:17:13.381 --> 00:17:17.965
cuz you're gonna use it and
just get used to it.

310
00:17:17.965 --> 00:17:19.298
>> I'm reloading the console right now.

311
00:17:19.298 --> 00:17:22.234
>> [LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH]

312
00:17:22.234 --> 00:17:23.709
>> That's the other way you learn.

313
00:17:23.709 --> 00:17:29.461
[CROSSTALK] So, but I can tell you that

00:17:29.461 --> 00:17:33.177
if you wanna do another one,
you can very easily,

00:17:33.177 --> 00:17:37.159
I'm sure all of you at this point,

can figure out any of the other ones on

00:17:42.670 --> 00:17:47.420
If I do a port scan and do XMAS.

318
00:17:47.420 --> 00:17:52.765
Remember, use, so use this Module,
and then give it the name.

00:17:52.765 --> 00:17:55.551
I didn't put auxiliary in front of it,
I could of and it would of been just fine.

320
00:17:55.551 --> 00:18:00.795
I hit Enter, and it's gonna load that in,
and boom, there we go.

321

You want to see how to configure it?

00:18:02.860 --> 00:18:03.740
Info.

00:18:03.740 --> 00:18:04.930
Boom, info comes up.

324
00:18:04.930 --> 00:18:06.600
This is what you can set.

325
00:18:06.600 --> 00:18:07.950
And this isn't any different.

326
00:18:07.950 --> 00:18:12.460
The info for this isn't any different
than it was for the SYN scan.

327
00:18:12.460 --> 00:18:15.960
I wouldn't really expect it to be.

328
00:18:15.960 --> 00:18:17.310
So it isn't any different.

If I wanted to, I could,

Set space, whatever the variable is,

So we do set, space, variable name.

And then, put space and

And then, Enter and it will tell you,

>> [LAUGH]

It tells you.

It tells you, hey, I set it to that or

I mean, I know that you can

00:19:13.351 --> 00:19:15.810
But anyway, great tool.

00:19:15.810 --> 00:19:18.495
Again, these are just scanners that

00:19:18.495 --> 00:19:20.829

It's got the scanners in.

And not just a port scanner, but

specialized scans, the SYN scans,
the XMAS scans, whatever the case may be.

358
00:19:36.407 --> 00:19:37.503
>> Like I said,

it's got a pretty broad amount of

00:19:43.590 --> 00:19:44.500
It's got it.

So we just did a SYN scan.

I brought up this XMAS scan, you can

00:19:52.480 --> 00:19:55.252
I mean, you can go through and

And then, you're done,

How easy can that be.

367
00:20:07.580 --> 00:20:12.160
So you're ready to go with those scans,
so if you're playing

along with this you should be able to run

No doubt if you grasped all the stuff

all that stuff I just told you, I have
no doubt that you could do a search for

00:20:23.737 --> 00:20:26.511
all the port scan stuff,

00:20:26.511 --> 00:20:27.371
>> Fantastic.
>> Yeah.

Now, some of them quite frankly you won't

If you don't have that,

That's part of that active intelligence

you guys.

This isn't homework.

But-

I think you probably

It's just kind of knowing

And that's something Sean, it seems like

I mean, that's kind of the way

I recognize what specifically

And so, that's kinda the cool

If you are really kinda going all out, and

>> [LAUGH]
>> There is a potential here,

since there's not much of a safety net.

You go ahead and tell it to target

432
00:23:51.055 --> 00:23:52.340
>> [LAUGH]
>> Fortunately,

the stuff we're doing up to this point,

00:23:56.210 --> 00:23:59.340
We're not to the point

a high chance of causing that problem.

But later on you could.

Which brings us to another point,

I mean, it's how you learn,

you will find out what not to do and what

443

That's how we all learn.

444
00:24:29.050 --> 00:24:30.700

>> Yeah, take your snapshots and

Maybe we can talk,

We'll talk about setting

Well, ladies and gentlemen looking at the
