episodes.title: Using a Vulnerability Scan
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.531
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:10.531 --> 00:00:13.630
Hello, welcome to another
episode of ITProTV.

3
00:00:13.630 --> 00:00:16.440
I'm your host Mike Rodrick, and
with me today is Mr. Sean Oriyano.

4
00:00:16.440 --> 00:00:17.410
How are you doing, Sean?

5
00:00:17.410 --> 00:00:18.330
>> I'm doing pretty good.

6
00:00:18.330 --> 00:00:18.990
How are you doing?

7
00:00:18.990 --> 00:00:20.170
>> I'm doing fantastic.

8
00:00:20.170 --> 00:00:21.860
Another exciting day here at ITProTV.

9
00:00:21.860 --> 00:00:24.700
We're gonna continue our
Metasploit series, and

10
00:00:24.700 --> 00:00:28.580
in this episode we're gonna be
talking about vulnerability scanners.

11
00:00:28.580 --> 00:00:31.930
We're gonna talk some concepts about
what they are, how we use them.

12
00:00:31.930 --> 00:00:35.160
I know you should be familiar at
least with the basics of them.

13
00:00:35.160 --> 00:00:38.260
And then we'll take a look later in
this episode or another episode.

14
00:00:38.260 --> 00:00:42.840
We'll take a look at using some of these
vulnerability scanners that are built into

15
00:00:42.840 --> 00:00:44.000
good old Metasploit.

16
00:00:44.000 --> 00:00:49.070
So, Sean, let's start off talking about
with what a vulnerability scanner is.

17
00:00:49.070 --> 00:00:51.190
Yeah, let's really position this.

18
00:00:52.440 --> 00:00:56.540
This whole segment or
session we need to really understand what

19
00:00:56.540 --> 00:01:00.440
a vulnerability scanner is, and
what vulnerability scanning is period.

20
00:01:01.600 --> 00:01:02.820
It's probably better for

21
00:01:02.820 --> 00:01:06.090
us to kinda look at the big issue,
what vulnerability scanning is.

22
00:01:06.090 --> 00:01:08.070
And vulnerability scanning is,

23
00:01:08.070 --> 00:01:12.170
really if you think about the name,
it kinda gets you there.

24
00:01:12.170 --> 00:01:15.070
But what are we really specifically doing?

25
00:01:15.070 --> 00:01:19.700
Well when we do vulnerability scanning,
it means we are in some way, shape, or

26
00:01:19.700 --> 00:01:25.390
form using processes and
techniques, or what have you.

27
00:01:25.390 --> 00:01:28.160
To look for weaknesses in a system, and

28
00:01:28.160 --> 00:01:32.820
that can be done any number of ways,
and it will be done any number of ways.

29
00:01:32.820 --> 00:01:35.390
The stuff we have in Metasploit,

30
00:01:35.390 --> 00:01:39.060
there's quite a few tools in there that
are specifically designed to look for

31
00:01:39.060 --> 00:01:42.870
vulnerabilities, as well as
leverage those vulnerabilities.

32
00:01:42.870 --> 00:01:47.250
As We've kind of already seen,
in some of our prior segments.

33
00:01:47.250 --> 00:01:50.670
So you can use Metasploit to do
some of those things manually.

34
00:01:50.670 --> 00:01:53.270
You can use Metasploit to
automate some of that.

35
00:01:53.270 --> 00:01:55.150
But you don't have to use Metasploit.

36
00:01:55.150 --> 00:01:56.440
You can use tools.

37
00:01:56.440 --> 00:02:02.260
Heck, end map would be in some circles
be considered with the right switches.

38
00:02:02.260 --> 00:02:06.910
Would fall under the category of
a vulnerability scanning utility.

39
00:02:06.910 --> 00:02:09.250
But it's not gonna be a complete one.

40
00:02:09.250 --> 00:02:12.470
If you wanna really kind
of bump up the stakes.

41
00:02:12.470 --> 00:02:17.460
We have full blown vulnerability scanners
in the form of, well the common ones

42
00:02:17.460 --> 00:02:22.980
we have are things like Nessus,
pretty much everyone's heard of that one.

43
00:02:22.980 --> 00:02:27.920
We have OpenVas built right in the Kali,

44
00:02:27.920 --> 00:02:32.177
which is a close cousin of Nessus.

45
00:02:32.177 --> 00:02:37.620
Then Metasploit actually has a relative in

46
00:02:37.620 --> 00:02:42.900
its product portfolio called Nexpose,
so Rapid7 puts that out.

47
00:02:42.900 --> 00:02:46.520
And you'll find those two
work really nice together.

48
00:02:46.520 --> 00:02:49.240
Imagine that, right?

49
00:02:49.240 --> 00:02:50.340
So you've got that.

50
00:02:50.340 --> 00:02:53.300
But there's plenty of
vulnerability scanners out there.

51
00:02:53.300 --> 00:02:57.870
There's some that even go way,
way up and above what we have access to,

52
00:02:57.870 --> 00:03:00.040
at a free or community level.

53
00:03:00.040 --> 00:03:04.870
And it's not just by a little bit,
it's by leaps and bounds.

54
00:03:04.870 --> 00:03:07.640
Heck, we looked at some of the other ones,

55
00:03:07.640 --> 00:03:12.680
even in our explanation of the forensics,
when we went through that course.

56
00:03:12.680 --> 00:03:16.910
We saw things like Netsparker and
stuff like that.

57
00:03:16.910 --> 00:03:19.190
So those are full blown suites, and yeah,

58
00:03:19.190 --> 00:03:21.870
you can really go to town with
this if you wanna spend the money.

Now, I'm gonna target those
vulnerabilities specifically.

286
00:16:34.080 --> 00:16:36.680
Now, that this guy found them,
I know where they are.

287
00:16:36.680 --> 00:16:40.310
Now, I can act on the ones
that really need my attention.

288
00:16:40.310 --> 00:16:42.440
Which is really cool.

289
00:16:42.440 --> 00:16:48.480
Something spots it, and then you just kind
of move in on those individual targets and

290
00:16:48.480 --> 00:16:50.000
focus your attention there.

291
00:16:50.000 --> 00:16:52.530
So that's a big, big, big help,

292
00:16:52.530 --> 00:16:57.010
and if you're looking at tools like
an expose, they're really good at it.

293
00:16:57.010 --> 00:16:57.885
Same company.

294
00:16:57.885 --> 00:16:58.494
>> Right.

295
00:16:58.494 --> 00:17:02.449
>> It finds it, and Metasploit comes
in and it's like, tag it and bag it.

296
00:17:02.449 --> 00:17:04.502
>> Oh really, good.
>> It goes in right there and does it.

297
00:17:04.502 --> 00:17:06.430
>> You mean, like here's five
exploits that'll hit that one.

298
00:17:06.430 --> 00:17:08.262
Which one would you
like to use type thing?

299
00:17:08.262 --> 00:17:08.910
>> Yeah.
>> [LAUGH]

300
00:17:08.910 --> 00:17:10.910
>> It could get to be that good if you

301
00:17:10.910 --> 00:17:12.110
really wanna go to town.

302
00:17:12.110 --> 00:17:18.410
Yeah, it can do that, and just for the
record, it's not to say that if you, if

303
00:17:18.410 --> 00:17:21.270
you have one off the other vulnerability
scanners you are kinda stuck,

304
00:17:21.270 --> 00:17:25.250
because, hey you didn't get an expose,
and now you want to use Metasploit.

305
00:17:25.250 --> 00:17:29.276
Oh well, you're gonna lose that
ability to get that close integration.

306
00:17:29.276 --> 00:17:33.302
It's not really that way,
because you can even use Nessus and

307
00:17:33.302 --> 00:17:37.794
export stuff to a standardized format,
usually it's like XML, for

308
00:17:37.794 --> 00:17:41.610
example, or
some sort of comma-delimited format.

309
00:17:41.610 --> 00:17:44.530
And you can take that, and
you can bring that into Metasploit.

310
00:17:44.530 --> 00:17:47.860
So remember, Metasploit does have
a database sitting back there.

311
00:17:47.860 --> 00:17:51.680
So you can actually create
a new section of that database,

312
00:17:51.680 --> 00:17:53.330
bring your results in, and

313
00:17:53.330 --> 00:17:58.410
then tell your tools to use those results
as their basis to do their scanning on.

314
00:17:58.410 --> 00:18:04.025
And operations on, so
you're not completely stuck there.

315
00:18:04.025 --> 00:18:06.470
In fact, I wanna say completely stuck,
it makes sense.

316
00:18:06.470 --> 00:18:08.723
It sounds like you're
actually losing something.

317
00:18:08.723 --> 00:18:13.497
You can say, yeah, you're probably losing
some of the ease of having expose in

318
00:18:13.497 --> 00:18:16.480
Metasploit, but
you can still get the job done.

319
00:18:16.480 --> 00:18:19.662
>> [CROSSTALK] Power of all
the different tools you can use, and

320
00:18:19.662 --> 00:18:23.159
you can still bring all of those to bear,
just not nice and tidy and

321
00:18:23.159 --> 00:18:26.423
the programs aren't maybe
talking to each other as easily.

322
00:18:26.423 --> 00:18:29.178
>> Yeah, for as me, as long as I get,

323
00:18:29.178 --> 00:18:34.880
as long as it's relatively easy for
me to do, and there's a point.

324
00:18:34.880 --> 00:18:37.033
You've got, everyone's gotta have
their own pain threshold on that.

325
00:18:37.033 --> 00:18:39.160
>> [LAUGH]
>> Really no other way to put it.

326
00:18:39.160 --> 00:18:41.502
Everyone's got their own pain threshold or
tolerance on that.

327
00:18:41.502 --> 00:18:46.460
You've got to decide just how much you're
gonna give up if you wanna use another

328
00:18:46.460 --> 00:18:50.014
vulnerability scanner and
integrate with Metasploit,

329
00:18:50.014 --> 00:18:53.710
is you've gotta decide just
how far apart those are.

330
00:18:53.710 --> 00:18:58.480
As far as what do you have to do between
here and here to make the two talk.

331
00:18:58.480 --> 00:19:03.040
Some of those things are gonna be, there's
a very, very small gap between the two and

332
00:19:03.040 --> 00:19:05.370
you just gotta do very little in here.

333
00:19:05.370 --> 00:19:10.840
Other one, I mean,
you've got a huge section between it

334
00:19:10.840 --> 00:19:15.960
that you've got to fill in yourself,
doing all sorts of things.

335
00:19:15.960 --> 00:19:17.730
Some people have come to the rescue.

336
00:19:19.070 --> 00:19:22.070
As far as that goes,
you have some vulnerability scanners,

337
00:19:22.070 --> 00:19:23.830
the more popular ones.

338
00:19:23.830 --> 00:19:25.950
Some people have third party.

339
00:19:25.950 --> 00:19:28.940
Other people have written little
plugins and stuff like that,

340
00:19:28.940 --> 00:19:29.790
that will bridge the gap.

341
00:19:29.790 --> 00:19:31.670
So that's kind of a cool thing.

342
00:19:31.670 --> 00:19:35.950
So those things can help you out, but
yeah, you've got to decide just how much

343
00:19:35.950 --> 00:19:39.260
work you're willing to do
in between those points.

344
00:19:39.260 --> 00:19:41.468
If you very close,
you don't have a lot of work to do.

345
00:19:41.468 --> 00:19:46.930
And if you're in the same CAD of expose
and the Metasploit camp are together.

346
00:19:46.930 --> 00:19:50.450
There's really nothing there,
it's a miniscule difference.

347
00:19:50.450 --> 00:19:55.180
If you go to the other ones, you have
varying degrees in there and for me,

348
00:19:55.180 --> 00:19:59.460
when I look about exchanging data
between programs, this goes back from my

349
00:19:59.460 --> 00:20:02.910
old mechanical engineering days when
I was supporting those guys and

350
00:20:02.910 --> 00:20:04.480
working with those guys.

351
00:20:04.480 --> 00:20:07.735
I remember working with the CAD programs,
and

352
00:20:07.735 --> 00:20:09.565
all these database programs at the time.

353
00:20:09.565 --> 00:20:13.605
And they would say, everybody was
pointing, oh it's perfect, 100%,

354
00:20:13.605 --> 00:20:15.172
data exchange, no problem, it's easy.

355
00:20:15.172 --> 00:20:18.125
>> [LAUGH]
>> And I was like, you're a liar.

356
00:20:18.125 --> 00:20:21.013
Nowadays, when I hear that, you go, you're
lying, and you know you're lying, and

357
00:20:21.013 --> 00:20:22.452
you look me in the face when you're lying.

358
00:20:22.452 --> 00:20:23.022
How dare you?

359
00:20:23.022 --> 00:20:24.230
[LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH]

360
00:20:24.230 --> 00:20:25.297
>> It's never 100%,

361
00:20:25.297 --> 00:20:27.850
you always lose something
in the translation.

362
00:20:27.850 --> 00:20:29.940
I always told clients at the time.

363
00:20:29.940 --> 00:20:33.700
And in the 20 plus years
since I was in that industry,

364
00:20:33.700 --> 00:20:34.710
that doesn't seem to change.

365
00:20:34.710 --> 00:20:37.190
When you move data from
one point to another and

366
00:20:37.190 --> 00:20:41.120
it's not the same application, you're
gonna lose something in the translation.

367
00:20:41.120 --> 00:20:44.920
Just be prepared for
it and you'll be fine.

368
00:20:44.920 --> 00:20:48.488
Maybe there are some people out
here who disagree with that, but

369
00:20:48.488 --> 00:20:50.153
that's been my experience.

370
00:20:50.153 --> 00:20:53.050
So you'll have to decide that here too,
just how much.

371
00:20:53.050 --> 00:20:57.500
Fortunately, it's gotten better,
because we do have formats like XML, and

372
00:20:57.500 --> 00:21:00.740
that has helped out tremendously.

373
00:21:00.740 --> 00:21:06.443
But you'll still run cases where
there's a big divide between those,

374
00:21:06.443 --> 00:21:11.873
that you're gonna have to find some
way to bridge it or deal with it.

375
00:21:11.873 --> 00:21:15.287
>> Nice thing about XML is, you can modify
it, maybe bring some of those tags that

376
00:21:15.287 --> 00:21:18.850
one program made that the other
program doesn't understand.

377
00:21:18.850 --> 00:21:19.840
So fantastic.

378
00:21:21.830 --> 00:21:24.410
That's a lot of information on
vulnerability scanners there,

379
00:21:24.410 --> 00:21:25.670
we're gonna use these.

380
00:21:25.670 --> 00:21:27.600
Whether we're doing it as
part of routine maintenance,

381
00:21:27.600 --> 00:21:32.570
or just audits on our network for
compliance, or if we're gonna use them

382
00:21:32.570 --> 00:21:37.530
as part of a penetration test that we've
been hired to do, or for our company.

383
00:21:37.530 --> 00:21:40.090
So a lot of uses for
these vulnerability scanners.

384
00:21:40.090 --> 00:21:43.220
We saw that there's actually
quite a few options we've got to.

385
00:21:43.220 --> 00:21:45.200
We can go with individual tools.

386
00:21:45.200 --> 00:21:47.210
We can go to full-blown suites.

387
00:21:47.210 --> 00:21:51.180
Reporting capabilities are gonna
be varied among the different

388
00:21:51.180 --> 00:21:52.690
vulnerability scanners.

389
00:21:52.690 --> 00:21:54.810
Most of them don't do any type of action.

390
00:21:54.810 --> 00:21:57.760
They're gonna report this
stuff back to us then, and

391
00:21:57.760 --> 00:22:00.340
then we're left on our own to
figure out what we wanna do.

392
00:22:00.340 --> 00:22:03.460
Whether we take that to the next step and
act on that vulnerability or

393
00:22:03.460 --> 00:22:05.710
whether it's just going into a report and
being turned in.

394
00:22:07.140 --> 00:22:07.940
A lot of good information.

395
00:22:07.940 --> 00:22:10.100
Sean, anything else we want to
throw in there when it comes to

396
00:22:10.100 --> 00:22:11.770
vulnerability scanners?

397
00:22:11.770 --> 00:22:16.200
>> I'll throw in one little detail on
this, just to make sure we're clear.

398
00:22:16.200 --> 00:22:19.643
Here, we're pretty much,
when we run a vulnerability scan, and

399
00:22:19.643 --> 00:22:23.884
we will do that we'll run a vulnerability
scan and we're kinda gonna say, yeah,

400
00:22:23.884 --> 00:22:27.100
stuff that we find we assume
we're gonna act on it.

401
00:22:27.100 --> 00:22:29.140
Just because something pops
up in a vulnerability scan,

402
00:22:29.140 --> 00:22:33.535
let me make it clear it's not something
that should send up a huge red flag.

403
00:22:33.535 --> 00:22:37.065
Or whatever, and you have to jump in and
do something about it.

404
00:22:37.065 --> 00:22:39.545
That's something that you have
to figure out when you look

405
00:22:39.545 --> 00:22:44.325
at those vulnerabilities, you'll have to
decide, is that a serious enough issue for

406
00:22:44.325 --> 00:22:49.360
you to go in and do something about it,
or you just leave it as it is.

407
00:22:49.360 --> 00:22:51.890
Nothing says because there is a problem

408
00:22:51.890 --> 00:22:55.570
that it perceives there that you
have to do something about it.

409
00:22:55.570 --> 00:22:56.650
So always remember that.

410
00:22:56.650 --> 00:22:59.900
Why we will be taking kind
of the stance here for

411
00:22:59.900 --> 00:23:04.680
the purposes of training you and getting
you prepped on Metasploit will be when you

412
00:23:04.680 --> 00:23:09.680
find some of these that we are gonna act
on them with folks on specific ones.

413
00:23:09.680 --> 00:23:12.810
But in the real world you find a bunch
of vulnerabilities, you can get

414
00:23:12.810 --> 00:23:16.380
a whole report and be all riddled with
vulnerabilities, and they're all low

415
00:23:16.380 --> 00:23:20.800
priority or none of them are a big deal,
and you're like, I know where they are.

416
00:23:20.800 --> 00:23:23.013
That's all you're really looking for
in the vulnerability scan.

417
00:23:23.013 --> 00:23:26.600
They're there, I know they're there,
do I need to do anything?

418
00:23:26.600 --> 00:23:28.630
Well, maybe not, probably not.

419
00:23:28.630 --> 00:23:32.180
It's just be aware of that.

420
00:23:32.180 --> 00:23:38.390
So don't get that confused with what
we do and the way the real world works.

421
00:23:38.390 --> 00:23:40.590
Because, like I said,
you may never do anything with it.

422
00:23:40.590 --> 00:23:43.760
You may run a vulnerability scan and
not touch anything.

423
00:23:43.760 --> 00:23:46.550
>> There's maybe some risk
management involved there.

424
00:23:46.550 --> 00:23:50.140
We start looking at them and going okay,
yeah, this might classify it as a risk,

425
00:23:50.140 --> 00:23:54.230
but to our network and in our scenario,
the cost to patch that up or

426
00:23:54.230 --> 00:24:00.380
prevent it, doesn't warrant the actually
following through with that.

427
00:24:00.380 --> 00:24:01.740
>> Yeah, that's absolutely correct.

428
00:24:01.740 --> 00:24:06.951
It is a risk management thing and a risk
assessment thing is just because it's

429
00:24:06.951 --> 00:24:12.012
there, doesn't mean that you need to
trip over yourself trying to fix it.

430
00:24:12.012 --> 00:24:16.520
And that's something that people that
are new to this do have problems with.

431
00:24:16.520 --> 00:24:17.330
They're like, oh my god.

432
00:24:17.330 --> 00:24:20.875
There's vulnerabilities or I need to
do something about it it's like no,

433
00:24:20.875 --> 00:24:25.357
you don't need to do anything about
it at all you can leave it as it is.

434
00:24:25.357 --> 00:24:27.775
It's kinda like saying you could have,

435
00:24:27.775 --> 00:24:33.735
in California where I live
you can say my house or

436
00:24:33.735 --> 00:24:38.935
a house down the street or
a warehouse is vulnerable to tornadoes.

437
00:24:38.935 --> 00:24:41.845
Oh, yeah, a tornado,
your house is tornado proof.

438
00:24:41.845 --> 00:24:44.725
It's like, and when's the last
time you heard a tornado up here?

439
00:24:44.725 --> 00:24:47.250
>> [LAUGH]
>> So they happen but not that often, so

440
00:24:47.250 --> 00:24:48.690
I'm not gonna freak out and

441
00:24:48.690 --> 00:24:51.610
go, oh, yeah, I need to kinda
go through and do some stuff.

442
00:24:51.610 --> 00:24:56.620
So just that's kind of a crude analogy,
but it works.

443
00:24:56.620 --> 00:24:57.780
You can see where I'm going with that.

444
00:24:57.780 --> 00:24:58.993
>> Absolutely.

445
00:24:58.993 --> 00:25:00.900
Well, Sean, a lot of good info there.

446
00:25:00.900 --> 00:25:02.520
We've got more episodes coming your way.

447
00:25:02.520 --> 00:25:05.870
We're gonna take a deeper look
into these vulnerability scanners.

448
00:25:05.870 --> 00:25:09.200
But for now, signing off for
ITProTV, I'm Mike Rodrick.

449
00:25:09.200 --> 00:25:10.220
And I'm Sean Oriyano.

450
00:25:10.220 --> 00:25:11.196
>> And we'll see you next time.

451
00:25:11.196 --> 00:25:17.450

00:00:17.760 --> 00:00:19.370

We are continuing on with our Metasploit

Because it's something that you

So that's what we have going on here.

paces and see just exactly what it can do.

24

>> Nice.

All right, lets take a look at it.

26
00:01:27.910 --> 00:01:29.890
Yeah, NetCat's one that's
been around forever.

27
00:01:29.890 --> 00:01:35.020
I think they call it the Swiss Army Knife
of tools, because it does quite a bit.

28
00:01:35.020 --> 00:01:37.670
>> Yeah, in fact they literally

It's the Swiss Army knife of tools, so

00:01:43.210 --> 00:01:47.470
I think we use that term a lot,

[LAUGH] And that,
that's a swiss army knife.

>> Well you know,
you got the different models right.

So you got the 10 piece,
the 24 piece, I don't know.

35
00:01:53.730 --> 00:01:54.280
>> There you go.

36
00:01:54.280 --> 00:01:56.034
If we had a whole product line.

37
00:01:56.034 --> 00:02:00.531
[LAUGH]
>> So, but, yeah it's, Netcat's,

00:02:00.531 --> 00:02:02.510
it's got some miles on it.

39
00:02:02.510 --> 00:02:04.210
I can't even remember how old it is.

40
00:02:04.210 --> 00:02:07.950
I know it's been around for quite a while.

So it's been around for quite a while.

It actually does have a cousin that you

That's newer and

So you can't eavesdrop on it which

46
00:02:27.500 --> 00:02:30.920

00:02:32.700 --> 00:02:37.020
But Netcat is,
obviously it's a command line utility.

You can use it to,

00:02:44.250 --> 00:02:49.490

00:03:01.610 --> 00:03:04.510
There's a way to do that right inside this

00:03:04.510 --> 00:03:07.610
program just using a few switches
to pass stuff back and forth.

57
00:03:07.610 --> 00:03:11.390
So it's really you know,
quite cool when you get down to it.

58
00:03:11.390 --> 00:03:16.670
You'll also find out when you look

it into obvious stages in here.

404
00:25:01.820 --> 00:25:06.470
And we've got,
this is the first stage of the process,

405
00:25:06.470 --> 00:25:07.830
you wanna make sure you grasp that.

406
00:25:07.830 --> 00:25:13.210
So we took the time to really understand
how things progress through, rather

407
00:25:13.210 --> 00:25:16.380
than just say, hey, I'm picking something
off the shelf and dropping it in.

408
00:25:16.380 --> 00:25:19.415
I showed you exactly what it was using.

409
00:25:19.415 --> 00:25:21.755
We talked, already,
about how to find things.

410
00:25:21.755 --> 00:25:25.785
Talked about which one we were using,
where it came into play,

411
00:25:25.785 --> 00:25:27.445
just went right on through.

412
00:25:27.445 --> 00:25:30.590
So we've got the first part of it done.

413
00:25:30.590 --> 00:25:34.490
So now, we get to in the next segment,

414
00:25:34.490 --> 00:25:39.540
have fun with the newly created
connection we have, that shell.

415
00:25:39.540 --> 00:25:41.769
And that really is a lot of fun, trust me.

416
00:25:41.769 --> 00:25:45.554
>> [LAUGH] I hope you guys are looking
forward to it as much as I am,

417
00:25:45.554 --> 00:25:46.510
I know I am.

418
00:25:46.510 --> 00:25:47.660
So, anyway.

419
00:25:47.660 --> 00:25:49.350
That's gonna do it for
this particular episode, though.

420
00:25:49.350 --> 00:25:52.290
So signing off for
ITProTV, I'm Mike Rodrick,

421
00:25:52.290 --> 00:25:53.220
>> And I'm Sean Oriyano.

422
00:25:53.220 --> 00:25:54.051

423

Now Sean we actually want to

16

that's where the fun really starts.

17
00:00:43.335 --> 00:00:46.160
>> [LAUGH]
>> I mean that's the thing we want to

18

We're going to bring a lot of

We had just got to a point where

22
00:00:58.820 --> 00:01:05.120
And we had confirmed that we actually had

23
00:01:05.120 --> 00:01:10.100
So we'd already got to
a pretty major point.

24

We got connections, we went through

25
00:01:14.610 --> 00:01:16.730
And to confirm that we were at that point.

26
00:01:16.730 --> 00:01:22.290
So we're in the zone I
guess is the way to say it.

27
00:01:22.290 --> 00:01:27.360
The question now is,
what are we gonna do at this point?

28
00:01:27.360 --> 00:01:33.530
Well there's seemingly an unlimited number

29
00:01:33.530 --> 00:01:37.550
It's just really kind of up

30
00:01:37.550 --> 00:01:40.311
You know, so,
when you have a Meterpreter up,

31
00:01:40.311 --> 00:01:43.600
Meterpreter gives you access
to all these system commands.

32
00:01:43.600 --> 00:01:48.920
it also gives you access to

33
00:01:48.920 --> 00:01:53.600
change the playing field dramatically
once you see, you know, what they are.

34
00:01:53.600 --> 00:01:58.440
It really does have a big,
big, big change on what you

35
00:01:58.440 --> 00:02:03.850
can do, and different actions
you can take at that point.

36
00:02:03.850 --> 00:02:07.492
So let's go back in to Meterpreter,

00:02:07.492 --> 00:02:12.310
I've got Meterpreter back

38
00:02:13.340 --> 00:02:17.950
And just to kind of
give you a peek over on

39
00:02:17.950 --> 00:02:23.020
what's happening on the XP system,
the XP system is just how I left it.

40
00:02:23.020 --> 00:02:26.130
So I do have that connection.

41
00:02:26.130 --> 00:02:30.600
You can see I just tabbed over and I

42
00:02:30.600 --> 00:02:32.350
But I've got, you know,

43
00:02:32.350 --> 00:02:36.140
here's the XP system,
there is no prompt open at the bottom.

44
00:02:36.140 --> 00:02:39.940
If I were to open up you know,
task manager and

45
00:02:39.940 --> 00:02:43.740
look at the processes running,
there's really nothing you know,

46
00:02:43.740 --> 00:02:46.430
jumping out at me that's out
of the ordinary in there.

47
00:02:46.430 --> 00:02:48.650
It looks all entirely normal.

48
00:02:48.650 --> 00:02:50.780
>> So as far as their concerned,
they don't know you're in there.

49
00:02:50.780 --> 00:02:52.650
>> Yeah, it's business as usual.

50
00:02:52.650 --> 00:02:57.010
Now, there's things they could look for,
but

51
00:02:57.010 --> 00:03:02.690
it's stuff that they're probably
not gonna look for just because.

52
00:03:02.690 --> 00:03:06.250
They're not gonna look for
it for no reason whatsoever.

53
00:03:06.250 --> 00:03:07.659
You'd have to do something to kind of

54
00:03:08.800 --> 00:03:12.200
stir up the hornet's nest I
guess is a way to put it.

55
00:03:12.200 --> 00:03:17.240
So I right now have a system that this

56
00:03:17.240 --> 00:03:22.340
person could be typing out,
sending an email or what have you.

57
00:03:23.500 --> 00:03:27.740
So I've got this system in here.

58
00:03:27.740 --> 00:03:30.990
So let me go back over to Kali.

59
00:03:30.990 --> 00:03:34.490
So we've confirmed that
that system is just fine.

60
00:03:34.490 --> 00:03:38.380
That person is not seeing
anything out of the ordinary.

61
00:03:38.380 --> 00:03:42.380
Like I said, we can do a sysinfo to
kinda get an our orientation in here,

62
00:03:42.380 --> 00:03:44.890
so that's pretty good.

63
00:03:44.890 --> 00:03:46.770
I can, there's commands in here like

64
00:03:47.910 --> 00:03:51.450
a PS command to give you a list of
processes that are currently running.

65
00:03:51.450 --> 00:03:55.330
So I'm going right through and
I'm seeing the processes that are,

66
00:03:55.330 --> 00:03:56.190
they're on the system.

67
00:03:56.190 --> 00:03:58.895
And we just went through the task right,

68
00:03:58.895 --> 00:04:00.785
and I didn't expect you
to memorize all that.

69
00:04:00.785 --> 00:04:04.485
But if you did you're insane,

70
00:04:04.485 --> 00:04:09.660
so we can see in here the stuff that's,
the stuff that's running.

71
00:04:09.660 --> 00:04:12.120
So that's pretty good.

72
00:04:12.120 --> 00:04:14.760
Okay so anything else we can do?

73
00:04:14.760 --> 00:04:16.960
Well yeah there are other
things we can do.

74
00:04:16.960 --> 00:04:20.470
You're not really done here.

75
00:04:20.470 --> 00:04:22.600
You can go through and

76

And do a quick screen shot of this and

77
00:04:28.910 --> 00:04:36.530
So let's say en route, let's go and

78
00:04:36.530 --> 00:04:37.850
It saved it right in the root.

79
00:04:37.850 --> 00:04:38.880
We got it.

80
00:04:38.880 --> 00:04:39.530
Is it right?

81
00:04:41.190 --> 00:04:42.359
There we go.

82
00:04:44.890 --> 00:04:45.865
Let's take a look.

83
00:04:45.865 --> 00:04:46.485
Oh, okay.

84
00:04:46.485 --> 00:04:48.250
Well, that looks pretty good.

85
00:04:48.250 --> 00:04:50.755
>> [LAUGH]
>> I don't know.

86
00:04:50.755 --> 00:04:54.315
You guys thinking at this point that hey,
maybe that's not right.

87
00:04:54.315 --> 00:04:57.073
It looks like it's a good match to me.

88
00:04:57.073 --> 00:04:58.275
>> [LAUGH]
>> So.

89
00:04:58.275 --> 00:04:59.625
>> [LAUGH] Yeah.

90
00:04:59.625 --> 00:05:00.530
Yeah, I'd say that's right on.

91
00:05:00.530 --> 00:05:01.855
[LAUGH]
>> Yeah.

92
00:05:01.855 --> 00:05:06.555
And so I've got a good shot at
this person's system so far.

93
00:05:06.555 --> 00:05:09.186
So that's a, that's encouraging.

94
00:05:09.186 --> 00:05:12.240
>> [LAUGH]
>> So what else do we wanna do?

95
00:05:13.270 --> 00:05:15.980
So I'm seeing that.

96
00:05:15.980 --> 00:05:19.840
That's a very good start to be off on.

97
00:05:19.840 --> 00:05:23.950
I can do plenty, and plenty, and
plenty of other things on here.

98
00:05:23.950 --> 00:05:28.370
Like I said, I've literally just started.

99
00:05:28.370 --> 00:05:32.580
I'm just going to give you a quick
look at the command list on here.

100
00:05:32.580 --> 00:05:36.480
I'm going to go through a lot of these
commands, and we're going to use these to

101

string several of these commands
together to do later actions.

102
00:05:41.690 --> 00:05:46.860
So, let's just take a quick
glance at the list hear.

103
00:05:46.860 --> 00:05:54.880
I mean, this thing has a pretty
decent list, as far as things go.

104
00:05:54.880 --> 00:05:57.570
I mean, you can see it's got, like I said,

105
00:05:57.570 --> 00:06:00.870
access to all the stuff
the normal system has access to.

106
00:06:00.870 --> 00:06:04.120
But then, I look at, you know,
some other things in here.

107
00:06:04.120 --> 00:06:07.880
As I go through the list,
you can see that it has stuff to help,

108
00:06:07.880 --> 00:06:10.150
to let us run this in the background.

109
00:06:10.150 --> 00:06:14.227
Push it to a lower priority,
so it's even less visible.

110
00:06:14.227 --> 00:06:17.780
You can load additional stuff.

111
00:06:17.780 --> 00:06:22.220
You can, you know, do all sorts of
little interesting things here.

112
00:06:22.220 --> 00:06:23.600
You can move it to another process.

113
00:06:23.600 --> 00:06:25.310
So right now it's just
sitting in one process,

114
00:06:25.310 --> 00:06:29.380
you could make it jump over to another one
if you wanted to hide it a little better.

115
00:06:29.380 --> 00:06:34.870
So that's already a few things you can do,
but

116
00:06:34.870 --> 00:06:36.980
let's look at some of the other things.

117
00:06:36.980 --> 00:06:41.880
When you get to the file system
commands in here, download a file.

118
00:06:41.880 --> 00:06:47.768
I can literally just go over to,
to my system that is got that,

119
00:06:47.768 --> 00:06:51.930
my Meterpreter open.

120
00:06:51.930 --> 00:06:55.040
Did I lose my Meterpreter in here?

121
00:06:55.040 --> 00:07:01.190
Yeah this is how you,
oh this is the system I got it on.

122
00:07:01.190 --> 00:07:04.290
This is how you get lost in things.

123
00:07:04.290 --> 00:07:07.790
So let's take a look,
see what we got going on here.

124
00:07:07.790 --> 00:07:10.740
There's, let's see,
there's some files there.

125
00:07:10.740 --> 00:07:17.740
Let's do download, and
let's see if we can do zipFLDR.dll.

126
00:07:17.740 --> 00:07:20.890
See if we can download that.

127
00:07:20.890 --> 00:07:23.570
Oh hey look, it went through and
downloaded that for me.

128
00:07:23.570 --> 00:07:28.410
So I'm pulling files off this person's
system already at this point.

129
00:07:28.410 --> 00:07:35.060
And notice I didn't say anything about
hey, what user am I logged in as?

130
00:07:35.060 --> 00:07:36.890
I just went right in.

131
00:07:36.890 --> 00:07:41.160
Some systems do support the who am I deal.

132
00:07:41.160 --> 00:07:44.520
This one doesn't, but
sometimes you can pull who am

133
00:07:44.520 --> 00:07:47.860
I depending on the operating system you,
you penetrated.

134
00:07:47.860 --> 00:07:52.210
sometimes it will tell you
what user you're running as.

135
00:07:52.210 --> 00:07:57.880
But right now,
I am just running as a regular user.

136
00:07:57.880 --> 00:08:02.183
We are going to work on bumping those up,
because we are not done with that.

137
00:08:02.183 --> 00:08:06.013
We are going to work on getting
more privileges in here, and

138
00:08:06.013 --> 00:08:08.003
just to kind of think about it,

139
00:08:08.003 --> 00:08:12.350
When we look at our hacking process
from before, what did we have?

140
00:08:12.350 --> 00:08:17.310
We scanned the system, we enumerated,
then we did things like

141
00:08:17.310 --> 00:08:21.070
cracking passwords and elevating
privileges and then going through and

142
00:08:21.070 --> 00:08:25.250
trying to clear tracks and all that and
put stuff behind to maintain access.

143
00:08:25.250 --> 00:08:30.060
So that's really kind of what we
are doing here, is we're gonna try to do

144
00:08:30.060 --> 00:08:34.210
the exact same process and we can do
it specifically with our interpreter.

145
00:08:35.640 --> 00:08:42.300
So what I wanna do is I'm gonna bring up
my help menu just one more time here,

146
00:08:42.300 --> 00:08:47.160
and go through a few other things.

147
00:08:47.160 --> 00:08:48.770
In here, just to kinda give you an idea,

148
00:08:48.770 --> 00:08:52.420
set up a few other little
details you can do in here.

149
00:08:52.420 --> 00:08:55.550
Notice, for the system commands in here,

150
00:08:55.550 --> 00:08:58.870
this is where it really starts to get
interesting and I ran the sysinfo.

151
00:08:58.870 --> 00:09:01.160
But take a look at some of the other
commands that are here on the list,

152
00:09:01.160 --> 00:09:02.580
that I'm gonna be using,
here, in a little bit.

153
00:09:03.810 --> 00:09:08.580
You have the ability to
get process ID's and

154
00:09:08.580 --> 00:09:14.950
get a SID, so if I get that SID I
can find out who I'm running as.

155
00:09:14.950 --> 00:09:15.570
>> Wow.

156
00:09:15.570 --> 00:09:20.615
>> I can even go through and use that
SID later on to impersonate that user.

157
00:09:20.615 --> 00:09:22.074
>> Hm, [LAUGH].

158
00:09:22.074 --> 00:09:25.430
>> So if I was to go through right now and
type in get SID.

159
00:09:27.510 --> 00:09:32.280
Through, hey, it's got a SID right there.

160
00:09:32.280 --> 00:09:35.630
I could do, what did I say,
a get process ID was the other one.

161
00:09:37.090 --> 00:09:39.820
It tells me what process ID
has been assigned to this.

162
00:09:39.820 --> 00:09:42.400
So it's starting to gain information.

163
00:09:42.400 --> 00:09:47.020
But let's do something

164
00:09:47.020 --> 00:09:52.130
along the lines of something that we
talked about in our CEH exploration.

165
00:09:52.130 --> 00:09:54.930
We talked about CEH,
one thing we talked about, like we said,

166
00:09:54.930 --> 00:09:57.002
was cracking passwords.

167
00:09:57.002 --> 00:10:02.500
You wanna be able to crack a password to
be able to gain access to an account.

168
00:10:02.500 --> 00:10:06.470
And you may not always get the account
that you want to have access to,

169
00:10:06.470 --> 00:10:10.800
so you may have to get
a lower privileged account.

170
00:10:10.800 --> 00:10:15.100
Okay so, what we have here at the
interpreter is that actually makes it even

171
00:10:15.100 --> 00:10:16.980
easier to do.

172
00:10:16.980 --> 00:10:21.940
It's almost cheating at this point,
how easy you can do things.

173
00:10:21.940 --> 00:10:25.530
So, if I want to crack a password,

174
00:10:25.530 --> 00:10:30.500
you've got really almost everything on
the table now, but, one of the things that

175
00:10:30.500 --> 00:10:35.120
in interpreter makes really, really easy
is, there's this command called hashdump,

176
00:10:36.380 --> 00:10:40.380
which if you run it,
it just goes like [COUGH] and

177
00:10:40.380 --> 00:10:46.950
pukes up all the stuff out of the SAM
database, so this is the local system now.

178
00:10:46.950 --> 00:10:48.880
Take a good look at what's there.

179
00:10:48.880 --> 00:10:53.630
It's nothing that, if you've gone through
our CEH and our forensics explorations,

180
00:10:53.630 --> 00:10:55.320
it's nothing that you haven't seen before.

181
00:10:55.320 --> 00:10:58.810
So what we're seeing is, we see
the administrative account, guest account,

182
00:10:58.810 --> 00:11:00.020
the help assistant.

183
00:11:00.020 --> 00:11:02.920
And Mike, you set this virtual machine up,
so you got an account on there.

184
00:11:02.920 --> 00:11:06.440
And then it's got one of our
other Windows XP accounts.

185
00:11:06.440 --> 00:11:09.280
And then after that, we have colon, and

186
00:11:09.280 --> 00:11:13.730
then an actual identifier for
the account, that unique ID for it.

187
00:11:13.730 --> 00:11:18.622
So we see 500, 501,
1,000, 1,003 and 1,002.

188
00:11:18.622 --> 00:11:22.800
Okay well you should
already kind of understand

189
00:11:22.800 --> 00:11:25.710
what those numbers mean even
if I blanked out the stuff

190
00:11:25.710 --> 00:11:30.010
right at the beginning of those lines to
tell you what the name of the account is.

191
00:11:30.010 --> 00:11:34.440
So I've got those first two things there,
so I know what account's which,

192
00:11:34.440 --> 00:11:37.175
I know the name and
the identifier that goes with it.

193
00:11:37.175 --> 00:11:37.690
>> All right.
>> But

194
00:11:37.690 --> 00:11:40.560
then let's kinda look over
at what we have after that.

195
00:11:40.560 --> 00:11:44.070
We have a bunch of whole crazy
characters sitting after it.

196
00:11:44.070 --> 00:11:49.130
Now, that's where we really kinda want
to focus our attention right now is,

197
00:11:49.130 --> 00:11:54.320
we look at those and
you should know if you've gone through and

198
00:11:54.320 --> 00:11:57.190
viewed the other material,
you should know what those are.

199
00:11:57.190 --> 00:12:01.110
You should know that's not just one
crazy string of characters there.

200
00:12:01.110 --> 00:12:04.960
There's actually two
things hiding in there.

201
00:12:04.960 --> 00:12:11.420
There's an LM hash, and there's also
the NTLM stuff in there too, okay.

202
00:12:11.420 --> 00:12:16.040
So we've got hashes there for
really all the accounts.

203
00:12:16.040 --> 00:12:19.090
We have learned actually a couple
of things here too by the way.

204
00:12:19.090 --> 00:12:20.740
We are seeing hashes.

205
00:12:20.740 --> 00:12:25.685
We know there is LM hash there, we can see
the NTLM stuff in there, but you're also

206
00:12:25.685 --> 00:12:32.285
learning that this person left that turned
on, that the storing of the LM hash,

207
00:12:32.285 --> 00:12:36.370
they could've gone on the registry or

in fact we've got more
Meterpreter coming your way.

468
00:26:27.290 --> 00:26:30.740
So if you thought that was cool
hang tight, we've got more.

469
00:26:30.740 --> 00:26:33.620
But for now signing off for
ITProTV, I'm Mike Rodrick.

470
00:26:33.620 --> 00:26:34.520
>> And I'm Sean Oriyano.

471
00:26:34.520 --> 00:26:35.810
>> And we'll see you next time.

472
00:26:35.810 --> 00:26:42.250

Even more fantastic, cooler, if that's

What we've done so far is,

nothing to sneeze at, really,

The question is, is that,

And what we're going do is we're going

So kind of a frightening thing when

But kinda cool when

>> Yeah, so
now you're telling me that after we've

That's what we're gonna do.

So that's what we've got, that's what

And so we're gonna see what that is and

You know with that, but just saying you

So let's kind of get into things and

Well you know, first of all just kind of

You can see that I have,

You'll notice that., I have,

So what I have is those keyscan commands.

Those ones will do exactly,

Those ones go through and

you can start intercepting keystrokes and

So you can dump that out to a file,

You actuall can look at files and

Text files, you can open them up remotely

You can do Cat and then the file name and

So that's another neat

all you gotta do to run that

And it's gonna stay like that

And when we're done you just do

It's turned off and between that I

you can even do it now, do a keyscan

I have a text file with all those

It would grab those things.

As long as they're pecking

it's gonna intercept those things.

In terms of you have capabilities, it's

So that's just one thing you can do.

Like I said, you can get passwords and

I can list my webcams on there,

I would be seeing that,

So and then you've got shad, if you

But of course, I think it kind of breaks

It's like hey, what are you doing?

I wouldn't consider that stealthy, but

hey everyone rolls a different way.

Here I just said record mic, it was

In fact you'll see down there, it also

It recorded it,

If they were, who knows?

You get this in the right situation and

00:08:48.620 --> 00:08:52.930
>> So we can capture keystrokes, we can

It's pretty impressive.

It's really come kind of a long way.

And then you can even

You could send keystrokes to that system,

And so you've got quite a bit

The Powershell one,

You're gonna see a remote desktop

then you can start browsing

165
00:10:05.690 --> 00:10:08.590
>> Wow, yeah.
>> So, there's kind of just the short,

a kind of a short look at what you could

And if you want to go third party and

So that would even take you one step

It's, you know so that's really

00:10:39.745 --> 00:10:40.850
>> Mm-hm, I'll say.

177
00:10:40.850 --> 00:10:43.660
All right a lot of good stuff there.

178

You know another one I think

00:10:49.020 --> 00:10:52.060
>> Yes.
>> Ways I can kill that, turn that off.

181

Yes.
That is another interesting

00:10:54.930 --> 00:10:55.820

183
00:10:55.820 --> 00:10:59.110
There are commands that you can run,

00:10:59.110 --> 00:11:01.920

00:11:01.920 --> 00:11:05.690
They have a specialized commands for

186
00:11:05.690 --> 00:11:10.870
just flip a switch and
terminate the execution of your antivirus,

187
00:11:10.870 --> 00:11:15.770
and once you have that out of the way,
you've got other stuff you can do now,

188
00:11:15.770 --> 00:11:19.110
because you're starting to
systematically disable their defences.

189
00:11:20.320 --> 00:11:23.860
You choose what you're gonna do at that
point, cuz now the stuff that you couldn't

190
00:11:23.860 --> 00:11:28.780
get in before, because the AntiVirus was
there blocking it, you've just put it so

191
00:11:28.780 --> 00:11:32.990
sleep, and
now you're putting stuff on the system.

192
00:11:32.990 --> 00:11:33.910
>> All right, wow.
>> And if you do,

193
00:11:33.910 --> 00:11:36.811
if you look through that list of things,
of commands,

194
00:11:36.811 --> 00:11:42.830

you may even have to kill the AntiVirus.

195
00:11:42.830 --> 00:11:47.390
There actually is the ability, on that

196
00:11:47.390 --> 00:11:50.340
a period of time, and so you may just find

197
00:11:50.340 --> 00:11:55.070
that you can suspend some of these
defensive processes just long enough

198
00:11:55.070 --> 00:11:59.130
to slip something on to the system to
be able to do what it needs to and

199
00:11:59.130 --> 00:12:03.200
take up residence there before you
bring those things back online.

200
00:12:03.200 --> 00:12:04.320
>> Wow.

201
00:12:04.320 --> 00:12:06.730
>> That's just another thing you can do.

202
00:12:06.730 --> 00:12:11.450
And then there's stuff to scrape all
sorts of information off a system and

203
00:12:11.450 --> 00:12:12.410
stuff like that.

204
00:12:12.410 --> 00:12:18.380
So you've got just a lot of little
features out here that are waiting for

205
00:12:18.380 --> 00:12:21.050

play around with them.

206
00:12:21.050 --> 00:12:22.362
>> Yeah.
That's pretty impressive.

207
00:12:22.362 --> 00:12:23.720
You know, my first thought was ooh,

208
00:12:23.720 --> 00:12:26.150
now if they will turn off their
AV I can get Netacad up there, but

00:12:26.150 --> 00:12:32.080
I don't really need it if I've got
Meterpreter running at this point right?

210
00:12:32.080 --> 00:12:33.230
>> Yeah.
If you

211
00:12:33.230 --> 00:12:37.900
are able to get a Meterpreter session
open, it gives you a lot, but

00:12:37.900 --> 00:12:42.910
you have got to think if you have
the Meterpreter session, you might be

00:12:42.910 --> 00:12:48.200
using it just briefly to drop something
off in the system to install it,

214
00:12:48.200 --> 00:12:53.270
and that way later on,
you can connect at will.

215
00:12:53.270 --> 00:13:00.110
This one, you have an active connection
that you've got on or it's just not being

216
00:13:00.110 --> 00:13:02.730
used, the other ones can sit there and
listen for you to come back at any time.

217
00:13:02.730 --> 00:13:03.340
>> Oh, okay.

218
00:13:03.340 --> 00:13:08.480
>> So, that might be a benefit
to having the other ones.

219
00:13:08.480 --> 00:13:13.770
I mean, there's no one tool that's gonna
solve really all the problems, but

220
00:13:15.150 --> 00:13:20.640
you can combine them to get something
that's greater than the sum of the parts.

221
00:13:20.640 --> 00:13:24.300
>> Alright, well really impressive
software there, Meterpreter.

222
00:13:24.300 --> 00:13:28.180
Anything else we wanna talk
about with Meterpreter?

223
00:13:28.180 --> 00:13:30.020
>> There are some other things you can do.

224
00:13:30.020 --> 00:13:32.460
There are some more advanced things that,
you know,

00:13:32.460 --> 00:13:35.280
I won't even worry about
getting into them in here.

226
00:13:35.280 --> 00:13:39.050
But you can create your own
specialized scripts that will

227
00:13:39.050 --> 00:13:41.160
run things in Meterpreter.

228
00:13:41.160 --> 00:13:44.750
You can actually also have
files that you can write

229
00:13:44.750 --> 00:13:48.700
that you can tell Meterpreter to

230
00:13:48.700 --> 00:13:53.330
run all the commands and it'll just run

231
00:13:53.330 --> 00:13:56.910
So you just have to issue a command
saying go read what's in that file and

232
00:13:56.910 --> 00:13:59.840
run this stuff, and it will take
care of all that stuff for you.

233
00:13:59.840 --> 00:14:03.135
So if you have a sequence of commands
that you'd like to go through,

234
00:14:03.135 --> 00:14:05.935
once you gain access to specific systems,

235
00:14:05.935 --> 00:14:10.975
you can essentially have a batch file
that just reads right through and

236
00:14:10.975 --> 00:14:13.950
runs these things for you,
and takes care of business.

237
00:14:13.950 --> 00:14:17.550
Yeah, so
there's little things like that that

238
00:14:17.550 --> 00:14:22.810
you can do to really kind of get more
mileage out of some of this stuff.

239
00:14:22.810 --> 00:14:23.570
>> Wow.

240
00:14:23.570 --> 00:14:25.680
Well, I tell you what, John,
that's a lot of good information.

241
00:14:25.680 --> 00:14:29.120
In quite a few episodes we
went over Meterpreter, so

242
00:14:29.120 --> 00:14:32.340
make sure you go back and

243
00:14:32.340 --> 00:14:37.130
because we basically took it from
beginning and a lot of good stuff there.

244
00:14:37.130 --> 00:14:40.510
Anything else we want to throw in
before we wrap this up, sew it up?

245
00:14:40.510 --> 00:14:42.840
>> Hey,
if you have time to experiment I think.

246
00:14:42.840 --> 00:14:46.510
That's what it is I think for all of you
out there, is really to experiment with

247
00:14:46.510 --> 00:14:51.660
this and start kicking the tires and
playing around and see what you can do.

248
00:14:51.660 --> 00:14:54.050
You will learn quite a bit, trust me.

249
00:14:54.050 --> 00:14:58.490
And give you a whole new appreciation
of things you can do, or

250
00:14:58.490 --> 00:15:02.650
of how powerful this product is once
you start playing around with it too.

251
00:15:02.650 --> 00:15:05.730
>> Absolutely, all right we hope
you enjoyed watching this episode,

252
00:15:05.730 --> 00:15:06.720
I know we enjoyed filming it.

253
00:15:06.720 --> 00:15:09.600
I'm signing off for
ITProTV I'm Mike Rodrick.

254
00:15:09.600 --> 00:15:10.330
>> And I'm Sean Oriyano.

255

In our Metasploit series and

>> Yeah, it is definitely

And what we're talking about in this

One of the things we hit upon briefly,

The social engineering toolkit,

And it was an interesting thing to look

00:01:36.460 --> 00:01:41.580

00:01:41.580 --> 00:01:45.470
So that's what we wanna kinda

00:01:45.470 --> 00:01:51.640
So you've seen it before, you've seen

00:01:51.640 --> 00:01:56.585
that it can do different types of phishing

00:01:56.585 --> 00:02:01.545
But we can also mix in some of

So some neat stuff, really.

But we really need to kind of understand

Because we've covered social engineering

It's one of those things that maybe

It's one of those things.

One that was the first time

And remember,

We're taking advantage of human nature,

Taking advantage of the fact that

00:02:52.172 --> 00:02:53.841

00:02:53.841 --> 00:02:58.052
that's why you wanna employ some

why it may be something that you'd

00:03:03.058 --> 00:03:07.984
process because you do have that weakest

00:03:07.984 --> 00:03:13.068
the system that maybe the easier thing

55

I think we in the CEH,

For example, you may just be

To ask someone, says what type of

Then just start talking to them and

Really couldn't consider that

But a lot of testers do

But how far you go with it or how much

it then you're probably not

much opportunity really to bring

So if you're doing, now if you're

00:04:48.210 --> 00:04:51.560
I could definitely see it employing or

00:04:51.560 --> 00:04:55.930

81

So what types of social engineering

We're talking like shoulder surfing, and

That would be a perfect example

00:05:23.680 --> 00:05:26.010

And then there's the dumpster diving is

an old-
>> [LAUGH]

But there's plenty of other ones

I want to say exploit.

00:05:39.173 --> 00:05:41.228
>> [LAUGH]
>> But that take advantage-

00:05:41.228 --> 00:05:42.255
>> [INAUDIBLE] [LAUGH]

>> Yeah, of things like not just human

nature and habit, but
things l like I said,

their trust,
other moral obligation to do something.

Kind of compelling them or

There's a number of things that human

it's just do you recognize

And once we've trained you how to do that

If you're doing name drop,

I call somebody on the phone, and

To make it look like it came

00:07:16.360 --> 00:07:23.080

So what we wanna do is see

And like you said, this kit is

But they are out there as

This is one of the ones that has gotten

Tools that we have out there

But if you get down to it,

We would as social engineers,

It depends on who I target I guess within

00:08:50.080 --> 00:08:52.083

00:08:52.083 --> 00:08:54.039
>> Sure, I think there's more

>> I've said a uniform.

And just walked into banks and

00:09:32.790 --> 00:09:37.590

00:09:37.590 --> 00:09:39.770
>> Which gave him a good reason

162
00:09:39.770 --> 00:09:41.494
>> Yeah, [CROSSTALK] exactly.

163
00:09:41.494 --> 00:09:45.382
And definitely to plug it into their

00:09:45.382 --> 00:09:49.410

165
00:09:49.410 --> 00:09:50.950
Oh well, that makes sense.

And guys getting escorted by the bank

00:09:56.460 --> 00:10:02.700

168

So it shows that yeah,
there's different forms.

169
00:10:06.550 --> 00:10:12.930
In this case, it was just a person that

170
00:10:12.930 --> 00:10:15.000
>> [LAUGH]
>> Probably just went through and

00:10:19.020 --> 00:10:20.990
That's probably all it took.

00:10:20.990 --> 00:10:25.885
So the bar can be kinda low [LAUGH] and
so, and some of these cases and

it worked for him.

He got in and was able to,

00:10:36.370 --> 00:10:40.016

178
00:10:40.016 --> 00:10:42.303
For this contacts say okay,

00:10:42.303 --> 00:10:45.435
Just stop, we've got other issues

00:10:45.435 --> 00:10:46.270
>> [LAUGH]
>> So-

>> I can just see the bank owner or

going time out okay, I give.

[LAUGH]
>> Yeah, and you definitely can picture

that type of scenario taking place,
that [LAUGH] so it was like oh yeah,

we gotta stop, we gotta take care

>> They probably had a big bank that
they've got regulations here in the states

00:11:13.223 --> 00:11:14.500
that they've got to follow.

00:11:14.500 --> 00:11:16.970

the problem is with social engineering,

00:11:21.070 --> 00:11:24.471

00:11:24.471 --> 00:11:27.822

00:11:27.822 --> 00:11:31.691

00:11:31.691 --> 00:11:33.735

00:11:54.520 --> 00:11:58.380

00:12:01.150 --> 00:12:04.410

00:12:05.910 --> 00:12:10.650
So you need to train people

00:12:10.650 --> 00:12:13.128

It's like anything you talk about but you

would say, so you develop a skill

00:12:25.250 --> 00:12:28.307

00:12:28.307 --> 00:12:30.225

It's not something that they're having to

00:12:33.711 --> 00:12:36.862

00:12:40.080 --> 00:12:43.938
But if I don't remind them constantly

00:12:43.938 --> 00:12:47.813
computer when you walk away things
like that, they forget, they get lazy.

216
00:12:47.813 --> 00:12:51.300
And so it's like you say,
it's a constant reminder.

217
00:12:51.300 --> 00:12:53.830
I know companies that put

218
00:12:53.830 --> 00:12:55.690

00:12:55.690 --> 00:13:00.280
My brother worked for a company that had

00:13:00.280 --> 00:13:03.900

221
00:13:03.900 --> 00:13:07.860
And a little message would pop up and

00:13:07.860 --> 00:13:11.390

don't leave your computer unlocked.

223
00:13:11.390 --> 00:13:13.565
And a little skit with monkeys involved,

00:13:13.565 --> 00:13:17.210
But the idea was,
it was a constant reminder,

00:13:17.210 --> 00:13:21.050
every time that computer went to sleep or

226
00:13:21.050 --> 00:13:22.880
They were reminded of that training,

so that's the kind of thing you have to

228
00:13:26.400 --> 00:13:31.083

242

Someone will do it cuz they may think

243

And those habits go away and so

When we run that thing,

making sure that the skills don't go away.

252

So yeah, we talked about it,

Kali was just a basic

A lot of good information there.

A little refresher on social engineering,

A lot of different hings will

you can see there, right now,
you can see the MSL prompt for

is sitting right there.

So that's just kind of a quick look,

you really don't even have to leave this,

You can still open up a command

In fact, if you look back at

I mean, I've got the command prompt

Once I go ahead and type r montage,

[LAUGH] And just stay over here.

And start doing whatever you want or

00:17:37.390 --> 00:17:40.660
That's what the interface looks like, just

00:17:40.660 --> 00:17:42.280

And we're gonna introduce

00:17:59.740 --> 00:18:03.495
So we've got a lot of exciting things,

00:18:03.495 --> 00:18:05.415
kinda go through this a bit more.

00:18:05.415 --> 00:18:06.035
>> Nice, nice.

Well I hope everybody out

00:18:08.595 --> 00:18:11.925

322
00:18:11.925 --> 00:18:14.865
So, Shawn,
anything you wanna leave with this,

00:18:14.865 --> 00:18:16.605
or throw in before we wrap this one up?

324
00:18:17.725 --> 00:18:20.455
>> Yeah, just to kinda leet you
understand, you know, where,

325
00:18:20.455 --> 00:18:25.325
just to kinda quickly, where this fits
into the whole scheme of things, and

326
00:18:25.325 --> 00:18:29.580
why you would actually want to use this.

327
00:18:29.580 --> 00:18:32.710
Where it fits in,
this is just an easier way,

328
00:18:32.710 --> 00:18:35.650
and a quicker way to do a lot of things
you would through Medasploit, and

329
00:18:35.650 --> 00:18:38.790
through your reconnaissance and
scanning phases, anyway.

330
00:18:38.790 --> 00:18:43.250
So that's kind of where it fits and
kinda why you would use

331
00:18:44.670 --> 00:18:47.950
it because it makes just easier,
makes things quicker for you.

332
00:18:47.950 --> 00:18:49.739
You know they kind of bill it as.

00:18:50.900 --> 00:18:55.560
As a quicker way to do pen testing.

00:18:55.560 --> 00:18:58.970
And I think you'll probably agree with
that statement after you've seen it,

335
00:18:58.970 --> 00:19:01.610
that it's a much quicker way to do things.

336
00:19:01.610 --> 00:19:06.170
So it's just something to
enhance your capabilities, but

337
00:19:06.170 --> 00:19:08.310
that's just one thing it can do.

338
00:19:08.310 --> 00:19:12.720
After you see all the stuff we're

00:19:12.720 --> 00:19:15.370
I'm sure you're probably, if you

00:19:15.370 --> 00:19:17.960
I'm sure you'll probably already

But there's some other things that

00:19:24.370 --> 00:19:25.950
One of the things they also

00:19:27.280 --> 00:19:32.400
bill Armitage as they bill it

00:19:32.400 --> 00:19:36.200
Which is, you know,
one of those Military terms,

that you hear used over there a lot.

00:19:38.600 --> 00:19:41.470
But you don't hear it

00:19:41.470 --> 00:19:46.375
But I think it's actually a very
appropriate term to be using here,

00:19:46.375 --> 00:19:51.245
because what a force multiplier
is supposed to do, it

00:19:51.245 --> 00:19:56.795
gives you much more power and
greater standing than you would otherwise.

351
00:19:56.795 --> 00:20:02.225
So when we look at a tool like this
it makes a single penetration tester

00:20:02.225 --> 00:20:04.165
greater than they would be on their own,
or

353
00:20:04.165 --> 00:20:07.980
enhances their skills more dramatically

00:20:07.980 --> 00:20:14.240
So, Armitage definitely does that just for

00:20:14.240 --> 00:20:20.130
But, if you really look at this tool,
it has the ability to let you work.

00:20:20.130 --> 00:20:25.940
They have this teaming type of concept,
where you can link up with

00:20:25.940 --> 00:20:31.320

00:20:31.320 --> 00:20:34.560
You can link up with them, and if you,

00:20:34.560 --> 00:20:38.170
and you have another member of your

360
00:20:38.170 --> 00:20:40.340
to take a look at something

00:20:40.340 --> 00:20:43.340
You can actually contact them

00:20:43.340 --> 00:20:47.190
they can have it running over there, and
then you can actually work together.

00:20:47.190 --> 00:20:49.080
So you can do that sort of thing.

364
00:20:49.080 --> 00:20:54.970
It's a weird concept in the overall scheme
of things, because it's kind of What?

00:20:56.350 --> 00:21:02.300
When you see it, there's not
really anything quite like that.

00:21:02.300 --> 00:21:05.470
As far as I'm concerned there's

00:21:05.470 --> 00:21:10.550
You might say that there are some
other rough things like it but,

368
00:21:10.550 --> 00:21:11.480
this one you really are.

00:21:11.480 --> 00:21:15.160
You can team up with other people
on your team that have this, and

00:21:15.160 --> 00:21:19.640
work together to do your penetration test.

371
00:21:19.640 --> 00:21:20.160
>> Nice.
>> And so

00:21:20.160 --> 00:21:24.630
that's a incredibly awesome

And then Armitage even

But it's related, it is related, but

It's not free, first of all,
it's called Cobalt Strike,

it is a much more powerful
Powerful tool that Armitage is.

Which is saying a lot.

00:21:47.785 --> 00:21:51.095
But it can do pretty much a lot of

00:21:51.095 --> 00:21:53.305
Plus it has all these extra capabilities.

It even has threat assessment and
management capabilities.

00:21:56.325 --> 00:21:58.947
It has reporting stuff and

And Armitage has the ability

00:22:01.347 --> 00:22:05.787
So it can actually team up with

385
00:22:05.787 --> 00:22:08.237
That tool runs about $3,500 per license.

386
00:22:08.237 --> 00:22:13.427
So unless you really got
a really good reason,

387
00:22:13.427 --> 00:22:15.767
you probably won't be touching that.

388
00:22:15.767 --> 00:22:17.367
>> But I think it is worth mentioning,

00:22:17.367 --> 00:22:22.040
because some of you might want to get

00:22:22.040 --> 00:22:26.140
our first few big jobs as apprentice, we

391
00:22:26.140 --> 00:22:28.150
>> Yeah,
that's really the name of the game.

392
00:22:28.150 --> 00:22:33.250
You get something like that that speeds
your capabilities up so much and

393
00:22:33.250 --> 00:22:38.910
you can get through these jobs much,
much quicker and turn them out.

394
00:22:38.910 --> 00:22:43.120
Yeah, that's peanuts as far as you're

00:22:43.120 --> 00:22:47.650
jobs, and make more money,
and be done with it.

396
00:22:47.650 --> 00:22:52.340
So, but that just kind of gives you where
it kind of fits in, and what it does, and

397
00:22:52.340 --> 00:22:56.090
we'll fill in some more of those gaps, and
blank spots that you may have in your head

00:22:56.090 --> 00:22:59.210

00:22:59.210 --> 00:22:59.720
Well don't worry.

400
00:22:59.720 --> 00:23:03.010
We're going to fill in some other
things with as we go through.

401
00:23:03.010 --> 00:23:03.540
>> Very good.

402
00:23:03.540 --> 00:23:04.590
All right, well, you heard it.

403
00:23:04.590 --> 00:23:06.300
Make sure you come back for

00:23:06.300 --> 00:23:09.450
We're gonna take a look at Armitage and

00:23:09.450 --> 00:23:12.700

So what our next step is to start

You bumped them off just by probing
them enough in rapid succession doing

396
00:23:19.770 --> 00:23:24.500
all of this and they actually
couldn't handle this and fell over.

397
00:23:24.500 --> 00:23:26.380
So there is that.

398
00:23:26.380 --> 00:23:27.840
And we do know that.

399
00:23:27.840 --> 00:23:32.710
We mentioned that in our CEH course.

400
00:23:32.710 --> 00:23:35.960
We were mentioning the fact that
pen testing, by its very nature,

401
00:23:37.160 --> 00:23:41.560
runs the risk of bumping something off,
of causing harm.

402
00:23:41.560 --> 00:23:46.780
So your client has to be the person
you have this contract with,

403
00:23:46.780 --> 00:23:47.990
needs to be aware of that.

404
00:23:47.990 --> 00:23:52.010
This isn't something
that's completely safe and

405
00:23:52.010 --> 00:23:54.900
there's not going to be any danger from
it just because you're a good guy.

406
00:23:54.900 --> 00:23:59.113
No there very well could be damage and
this is something that could also do that.

407
00:23:59.113 --> 00:24:00.883
You could very well using this tool.

408
00:24:00.883 --> 00:24:06.550
Cause some sort of damage or problem and
then you've got to go and fix that.

409
00:24:06.550 --> 00:24:09.850
You may not have even run
an exploit at that point.

410
00:24:09.850 --> 00:24:12.580
You just found what exploits will work,
and all of a sudden just boom.

411
00:24:12.580 --> 00:24:14.350
It's, something fell over,

412
00:24:14.350 --> 00:24:17.920
got destroyed and now they're
looking at you going, what'd you do?

413
00:24:17.920 --> 00:24:23.960
So, just be aware of that little
detail on there, as well.

414
00:24:23.960 --> 00:24:27.170
But, yeah, we ran it,
we swept all five of our hosts on here.

415
00:24:27.170 --> 00:24:30.035
You saw the stuff just go shooting by and

416
00:24:30.035 --> 00:24:34.775
tell us that hey,
I found some stuff that works and so

417
00:24:34.775 --> 00:24:38.675
we could actually go through and try some
of those now if we really wanted to.

418
00:24:38.675 --> 00:24:39.725
>> Fantastic, all right.

419
00:24:39.725 --> 00:24:44.275
Well another great look at Armitage and
what we can do with that.

420
00:24:44.275 --> 00:24:47.845
This time, a little more focused
on the client side exploits and

421
00:24:47.845 --> 00:24:49.285
some of the payloads we can deliver there.

422
00:24:49.285 --> 00:24:51.215
And then of course everybody's favorite,
or

423
00:24:51.215 --> 00:24:52.950
at least my favorite so
far, The Hail Mary.

424
00:24:52.950 --> 00:24:56.220
Just take everything you've got and
throw it out.

425
00:24:56.220 --> 00:24:57.990
[LAUGH] Something's gotta stick, right?

426
00:24:57.990 --> 00:24:59.320
Who cares about alarms?

427
00:24:59.320 --> 00:25:00.630
We're not worried about that.

428
00:25:00.630 --> 00:25:01.240
[LAUGH]
>> Exactly.

429
00:25:02.250 --> 00:25:03.590
>> All right, well,
Sean, lot of good info.

430
00:25:03.590 --> 00:25:07.750
Anything else we want to throw
in before we wrap this one up?

431
00:25:07.750 --> 00:25:11.380
>> Let me just emphasize the point to
kinda boil a lot of this stuff away.

432
00:25:11.380 --> 00:25:14.580
You know, since we were just talking
about the Hail Mary stuff, but.

433
00:25:14.580 --> 00:25:18.630
Make sure you're aware of the fact that,
just because you can't get

434
00:25:18.630 --> 00:25:23.500
a remote exploit going on a system, it
doesn't mean that's the end of the road.

435
00:25:23.500 --> 00:25:30.570
You still have those client side attacks
to try, and see where that gets you.

436
00:25:30.570 --> 00:25:36.640
Cuz that may get you some movement,
where the other ones will not.

437
00:25:36.640 --> 00:25:39.540
So just be aware that
people have gotten smarter.

438
00:25:39.540 --> 00:25:42.780
System admins have gotten smarter.

439
00:25:42.780 --> 00:25:47.250
IT people have gotten smarter, and we have
a lot more tools that help us do patch

440
00:25:47.250 --> 00:25:49.250
management and all that type of stuff.

441
00:25:49.250 --> 00:25:54.220
That have raised the bar on things and
made it a little bit more difficult for

442
00:25:54.220 --> 00:25:57.860
some of this stuff to work, the normal
exploits that we've seen to work.

443
00:25:57.860 --> 00:25:59.860
So you might need to
resort to something else.

444
00:25:59.860 --> 00:26:03.690
But that's actually good that we
have the ability to switch over,

445
00:26:03.690 --> 00:26:05.080
even in regular Metasploit.

446
00:26:05.080 --> 00:26:07.340
You could have done
the clients at exploits,

447
00:26:07.340 --> 00:26:10.040
you could do those in regular Metasploit.

448
00:26:10.040 --> 00:26:13.270
We just didn't do them over there,
because it's just more going use and

449
00:26:13.270 --> 00:26:17.190
all those things for
showing that we did for remote code stuff.

450
00:26:17.190 --> 00:26:18.730
It's the same type of thing.

451
00:26:18.730 --> 00:26:21.300
They're configured just a little
slightly differently because it is on

452
00:26:21.300 --> 00:26:22.470
the client side.

453
00:26:22.470 --> 00:26:26.390
But it's just more kind of
the same type of thing.

454
00:26:26.390 --> 00:26:30.100
But this was just kinda just to tell you,
I saved them to this point just to kinda

455
00:26:30.100 --> 00:26:32.830
tell you hey, not only can
Armitage do something like that,

456
00:26:32.830 --> 00:26:35.900
Metasploit itself because Armitage
is running Metasploit for you.

457
00:26:35.900 --> 00:26:41.020
You can do that right through Metasploit
and it's another avenue of attack.

458
00:26:41.020 --> 00:26:42.770
So you, do have these options.

459
00:26:42.770 --> 00:26:44.810
If one doesn't work,
you can switch over to another one.

460
00:26:44.810 --> 00:26:46.490
It gives you flexibility.

461
00:26:46.490 --> 00:26:47.240
Very good.

462
00:26:47.240 --> 00:26:49.630
All right and I know what I've done
Sean and we've got more to do.

463
00:26:49.630 --> 00:26:52.500
We want to take a look at, and
once we've done those exploits,

464
00:26:52.500 --> 00:26:57.140
maybe the next step or
what we can do once we've.

465
00:26:57.140 --> 00:26:59.250
I can't think of a good way to say it,

466
00:26:59.250 --> 00:27:02.390
once we've done one of these
exploits on those machines.

467
00:27:02.390 --> 00:27:05.640
So, but
that's going to come up in later episode.

468
00:27:05.640 --> 00:27:08.693
So for now signing off for
ITProTV I'm Mike Roderick.

469
00:27:08.693 --> 00:27:09.814
>> And I'm Sean Oriyano.

470
00:27:09.814 --> 00:27:11.201
>> And we'll see you next time.

471
00:27:11.201 --> 00:27:17.080
[MUSIC]

Also notice, and

Also notice, when you are doing this,

Oh, well, look, it's right there, I didn't

If you are doing your

After playing with Armitage for a while,

Well, there's a handful of other

what we're gonna talk about is kinda

Here, or
kind of narrow it down to kind of,

as closely as we can because you can

00:01:15.216 --> 00:01:20.383
And what we mean by that is when you
gain access to a network, so let's say

25

you're doing this remotely or you're just
trying to get further into a network.

So you get hit with a subnet, and

you sweep the subnet like we did and

Well, you find these hosts and you start

So that got us some mileage.

Well, you're not really gonna stop there.

You just don't stop at that point.

You've got other things that you can do.

And what we're typically gonna
do is once we get that foothold,

Now, the way we do that is Armitage

And you can do this right through
Metasploit again if you want to run all

But, Armitage makes it a lot easier as

00:02:26.940 --> 00:02:31.770
So what I have here on my system

00:02:31.770 --> 00:02:36.640
here is I've got my Armitage
window up once again.

00:02:36.640 --> 00:02:41.340
You can see that I have the two
systems actually compromised.

44
00:02:41.340 --> 00:02:42.090
I can see that.

45
00:02:42.090 --> 00:02:45.370
So I've got the little lightning bolts and
everything around it.

46
00:02:45.370 --> 00:02:48.110
And notice it's confirming

47
00:02:48.110 --> 00:02:50.610
And both have root on
Metasploitable system,

00:02:50.610 --> 00:02:52.320
move all the way over on the right.

49
00:02:52.320 --> 00:02:55.810
And then, have the system on
the Win XP system on the other one.

50
00:02:55.810 --> 00:02:59.740
So I've got access, I'm in.

51
00:02:59.740 --> 00:03:04.640
We know that, I can see the shells open
at the bottom, so I'm kinda rocking and

52
00:03:04.640 --> 00:03:05.310
rolling here.

53
00:03:06.455 --> 00:03:11.925
So what you can do is when you
get into a system at that level,

00:03:11.925 --> 00:03:17.285
there's additional steps would be get it

55
00:03:17.285 --> 00:03:20.960
Is there any way I can jump off

56
00:03:20.960 --> 00:03:24.930
So one of the things that helps
you do with that is there's

00:03:24.930 --> 00:03:29.895
something called pivoting which is
what we mean in this whole section,

58
00:03:29.895 --> 00:03:32.644
the starting of it is pivoting rather.

59
00:03:32.644 --> 00:03:37.570
And what pivoting is means that you're
gonna be trying to hit another subnet.

60
00:03:37.570 --> 00:03:39.495
You discover another subnet or
another system.

61
00:03:39.495 --> 00:03:45.474
And you're gonna start, keep moving
through, doing that whole thing.

62
00:03:45.474 --> 00:03:51.010
So what I have here on, for
example, my Win XP system.

63
00:03:51.010 --> 00:03:52.890
That's been compromised.

64
00:03:52.890 --> 00:03:58.180
What I can do is, I can go right on

65
00:03:58.180 --> 00:04:04.410
you can see it has a set up
option in here, and it's saying,

66
00:04:04.410 --> 00:04:10.885
I recognize this as a subnet
that this thing's attached to.

67
00:04:10.885 --> 00:04:14.850
I can go through and do add pivot, and you
can see it when I click on it, it gonna

68
00:04:14.850 --> 00:04:18.944
say added to route, and you can see right
across the top, it added a green line.

69
00:04:18.944 --> 00:04:24.170
Now, the way it is right now, I'm not
accessing another subnet off this system,

70
00:04:24.170 --> 00:04:29.095
everything is on this system so it's
just gonna be doing between these guys,

71
00:04:29.095 --> 00:04:33.563
but if it had other targets,
other subnets, I would just choose it and

72
00:04:33.563 --> 00:04:38.300
it would start showing me
the connections that are being done.

73
00:04:38.300 --> 00:04:41.100
And that connection,
the really cool thing about it is,

74
00:04:41.100 --> 00:04:44.810
is that as it becomes active and
you start doing stuff across it,

75
00:04:44.810 --> 00:04:48.630
you'll see it get highlighted, telling you
that there's activity going across it.

76
00:04:48.630 --> 00:04:51.573
And so, you're seeing
the relationships right here,

77
00:04:51.573 --> 00:04:55.089
quite quickly telling you that,
hey, there's something here.

78
00:04:55.089 --> 00:04:59.474
In fact, if you look at it, you can

79
00:04:59.474 --> 00:05:03.410
You can see a dark,
kinda faded out green arrow.

80
00:05:03.410 --> 00:05:06.260
There's nothing happening
with that connection.

81
00:05:06.260 --> 00:05:11.950
It's saying, yeah, I recognize it,
and you can even see behind this

82
00:05:11.950 --> 00:05:17.590
bright green arrow, you can see that there
actually is some other little dark green

83
00:05:17.590 --> 00:05:21.190
stuff showing out that's saying there's
nothing really going on between those.

84
00:05:21.190 --> 00:05:25.687
It's not an active connection.

85
00:05:25.687 --> 00:05:29.070
So I've got a pivot added in there.

86
00:05:29.070 --> 00:05:34.610
Now, if you were to go into one of
these systems, let's say I go to my

87
00:05:36.360 --> 00:05:43.780
XP system here, I could go and look at it
and do things like ipconfig, for example.

88
00:05:43.780 --> 00:05:47.970
And have it spit out and
say what networks it's attached to.

89
00:05:47.970 --> 00:05:52.980
Here, I only see it's attached
to one network specifically.

90
00:05:52.980 --> 00:05:57.929
But if this thing was attached to multiple
networks or multiple network adapters,

91
00:05:57.929 --> 00:05:59.916
maybe I'd find another subnet.

92
00:05:59.916 --> 00:06:03.054
And I could see if I can
push through that, perhaps.

93
00:06:03.054 --> 00:06:07.258
As it is, right here,
I see a gateway in place in there.

94
00:06:07.258 --> 00:06:09.370
Let's see if the gateway is alive.

95
00:06:09.370 --> 00:06:16.430
I could do, just regular commands that
I would do, as if I was sitting there.

96
00:06:16.430 --> 00:06:20.228
So I'm pinging it to see if
I'm getting any life from it.

97
00:06:20.228 --> 00:06:21.308
Maybe that system isn't on.

98
00:06:21.308 --> 00:06:25.320
It doesn't look like it's kinda
sitting there, not doing anything.

99
00:06:25.320 --> 00:06:30.260
So maybe that system isn't online or
thinks it's there, or for

100
00:06:30.260 --> 00:06:32.620
some reason we're not getting a response.

101
00:06:32.620 --> 00:06:36.536
But I do actually see it
